column11: Review Text
The clearest, blue water I have ever seen.  Hardly anyone there, you have to pay a small fee to enter but it's well worth it.  Lots of little bars and restaurants scattered about.

This has always been my favourite beach in Tobago. This year for my birthday all I wanted to do was just relax on the beach for the week and I got to do exactly that this year. My partner and I got the Chillaxx package (please see photos for prices) which was a great deal for the week while we stayed there. The staff on the beach were always very friendly and helpful. I was pleasantly surprised to see that there was a hut that made pies. Their aloo pie and beef pie was very tasty and reasonably priced. I have a favourite spot that I like to have my chairs at and it is closer to the rocks and farther away from the jetty. My family had complained about their being a drop off, which made it hard for them to get in and out of the water back during Easter. My partner and I did not experience any of that this time we went and it was easy for us to get in and out of the water and there were young children there as well and they didn‚Äôt have any problem. My friend was vacationing in Tobago during the summer and spoke about a lot of seaweed coming into shore. Again, my partner and I did not experience any of this. There was actually very little seaweed. There were a lot of fishes in the ocean coming right up to shore, which I‚Äôve never experienced this amount before. It made for a very interesting experience as there were random yelps and it cost quite a few bathers off guard.

This place is postcard perfect. Clear turquoise water, safe for the children, and we rented a little cabana on one day for shade. Entrance fee was reasonable and the facilities were good. Perfect spot to relax all day.

Just got back from nearly a week in Tobago and am having a vacation tabanca! Pigeon Point Beach was like something from a postcard - white sand, clear blue water, and palm trees. We rented chairs with a view of the thatched roof jetty and spent the day swimming and sipping cocktails from the bar there. The reef nearby was perfect for snorkeling, even for beginners like me, take a glass bottom boat. Don't miss the sunset here - it's magical. Will definitely return!
Wonderful beach lovely safe waters great service and bar.  Drinks very reasonable we had a shack which easily seated 8 and offered good shade

column8: Beat de iron while it hot
column11: Visiting Tobago and not visiting Pigeon Point is to  'beat de iron while it hot', as you have to experience the beauty of this national park/beach whilst there.  It's the jump off spot for No Man's Land, Bucco Reef, Nylon Pool boat trips.  You pay a small entry fee to use the beach and the facilities.  You then have to pay for the umbrella, beds, chairs, cabins or bring your own stuff and try and find shade. Due to motorsports accidents there is now an area cordoned off by buoys, make sure you use this area as there are jet skis, fishermen, glass bottom boats everywhere. Don't jump off the end of the jetty - a Caribbean Island Pilot jumped off last week and broke his neck in 2 places as he hit a rock. It's relaxing, but loud, everyone playing different music, but that's the vibe - people are relaxed and there are places serving food (fast food) and drinks.  Some nice shops at the back, check out the pottery/ceramic shop they have beautiful windchimes. AVOID Cruise Ship Day - check the forecast as it will heaving and change the vibe.

The beach is terrific with warm and clear waters.  But, we witnessed a spinal injury resulting in a cardiac arrest.  The lifeguards were passive, bystanders provided all the medical care.  The nurse providing chest compressions kept calling out for a defibrillator, but there wasn't one onsite.  How can that be?  The premier beach on the island, where you pay admission, with lifeguards on duty and no defibrillator?  That needs to change immediately.

We visited the beach three time during our recent trip to Tobago. The beach is worth all the hype, typical Caribbean views, soft sand and turquoise coloured waters!! Get there early 'to bag' an umbrella there are only 25 for the whole beach. Sun loungers are very good. Two restaurants at either end selling decent food and cold beer! The showers and toilets were excellent. And the chaps putting out the beds worked really hard all day. The only downside is if there is a Cruise ship in port, the beach gets very, very busy with often a couple of thousand passengers. This is your reviewers idea of Dante's second level of hell! Avoid if you can. Costs - 44ttd = Entry, Umbrella = 15ttd & Sunbed = 15ttd Recommended

Beautiful beach with affordable accommodation, bars and restaurants and the possibility to rent sunbeds for 5$, they also accept ‚Ç¨. Sunbeds can be placed directly under palm trees or other vegetation on the beach. The only drawback: the sea in the area protected by floating lines is shallow, despite the line is also far from the shore and going beyond it is very dangerous as boats and jet skis pass at high speed, in any case there are lifeguards who call people imprudent.
Excellent beach with restrooms and restaurants. Maybe a bit overcrowded but still worth the entrance fee. Pay with card at the bar and it‚Äôs cheaper than paying in US $ .!

We came out of port and were approached by several taxi van operators all touting for excursions. I think they were asking $40  per couple. Kept walking, they follow and drop price, got it for $30 . Agree the return time and driver comes to collect. Only paid one way so no fear of being left. Driver arrived 15 mins early so got back to ship in good time. Regarding the beach, the pics are,as usual , are not the true representation. It was a bit narrow and sun beds were quite crammed and knackered. They wanted $25 for a pair and parasol. It‚Äôs an okay beach but I wouldn‚Äôt go again.
Beautiful nature reserve, affordable prices, wonderful sea even if too salty. There is the beach bar, accessible by a free boat from the beach. I highly recommend

Scenic beach with white powdery sand and calm turquois blue water. Great sunset spot. The jetty stretching into the water is very photogenic. There is an entrance fee, but the beach has good facilities with restrooms, showers, concessions selling beer and snacks and a beach bar. There is also plenty of parking. It is kept clean and well maintained and there are lifeguards. Chaise lounges and umbrellas can be rented. There are also no vendors bothering you on the beach. However, it is a bit too commercialized for my liking as I prefer more authentic less developed beaches. Additionally, it is an extremely popular beach, maybe the most popular on Tobago and it can get busy.  It's not a place for peace and quiet but is a place to have fun. Nothing wrong with that but know what to expect.

You must pay to enter, then pay for sun loungers, pay for sun umbrella, pay for everything! It's a takeoff point for glass-bottom boat trips out to the reef, which are good for snorkelling and good fun.

Pigeon Point Beach is probably the most iconic and most photographed spot in Tobago. The jetty is perfect for photos and the surrounding beach is stunning. You pay a small cover charge to enter which is worth is as it's well maintained, lifeguards, restaurants, shops, watersports, facilities with showers are all there. It can get really busy at peak times, we prefer it quieter but the picturesque views are amazing and it's reputation is well deserved.
Best place to relax and do truck all!! Wife and I just finished our honeymoon and man o man was this place amazing. And the rain held off !!

A beautiful beach cove set in a lovely national park location.  The entrance fee is TTD 20 per person and we hired 2 sunbeds and 1 sun brolly for a total of TTD120. They were set up  right on the front of the beach and were in good condition. The beach itself was very clean and there were areas where you could shade under the trees if preferred. Their were well maintained toilets and showers, an ice cream booth and 2 bars (one at either end of the beach). I would estimate that the beach stretches out for around 400m. The sea was relatively calm and there are a couple of small coral sand steps to negotiate entering and exiting the sea. There is a protective boundary for safe swimming as there are various boats and jet skis around. It's a great location for adults and families. We enjoyed 2 lovely days visiting this beach as our hotel was based on the Atlantic coast with no beach to access.

We came to Pigeon Point twice whilst staying on Tobago. A wonderful natural park on the edge of a white sandy beach, and clear blue sea! It‚Äôs only around ¬£2.50 to enter for the day, and sun loungers cost about ¬£4 each. There‚Äôs a few water activities that you can partake in, also a boat trip which lasts around 3 hours. Food is also available. There‚Äôs a bar/restaurant, as well traditional Tobagan street food ( that‚Äôs what we had, and it was delicious, and very cheap!) All in all a relaxing day!

Pigeon Point has become a very commercial Disney-like attraction with tacky bars and pricing for almost everything - shades, sunbeds (warning signs "one sun-bed per person - not to be shared'. The two little beaches are crowded and when we were there mid-week, there were local groups with ghetto-blasters scattered around hence zero tranquility. The food quality was rubbish and for those who expect a 'tropical paradise' it has become all very commercial. The only saving grace was the entrance fee of about US$2. We had a quick swim in the rough water, a drink and fled. Much better beaches to see in amazing Tobago!

Amazing paradise beach, fringed with palm trees. Beautiful way to relax.  Entry fee to the park 20 TTD per person.  We snorkelled at the point and booked a night time marine safari with Brett at Radical Sports Limited Tobago.  Great bioluminescent seen by kayaking to the Bon Accord Lagoon.  Weather and moon cycle aligned for our stay in Tobago.  Also hired paddle boards with Brett.  Caught the Sugar Lips boat to Buccoo Reef and Nylon Pool.  Great trip organised by our tour provider.  A really lovely place to be.

Great beach, very clean, felt safe, loved the beautiful ceramics shop within the complex. Could easily stay for the day. We were surprised how cheap drinks were, we thought they‚Äôd be more expensive here. Overall a great place to visit, can imagine it gets busy in peak season.
This is my favorite beach in Tobago‚Ä¶.talking from the serenity to the water to vibes to the bars, etc‚Ä¶I love sunset hour at this beach

The first beach that was so calm and peaceful I fell asleep.  i am not sure if it was the sound of the calming waters, the soothing ocean breeze or the palm trees that were swaying- but it was an amazing experience.

Paid the entrance fee($20 per adult), paid for 2 chairs and an umbrella ($90)for the 3 of us only to be told bythe workers there there that not more that one person can sit on the chair! Imagine renting a chair and then being told how to use it! Sort it‚Äôs a ridiculous rule that no other beach follows! Save your money and just lay out on the sand!

Pigeon Point Beach is everything you expect from a Caribbean beach and more. With its thatched roof jetty, clear waters, and palm-fringed shore, it's picture perfect. The amenities are excellent, including restaurants and water sports rentals. Perfect for a day out!
One of the most beautiful pristine beaches in the world. I would definitely recommend anyone to visit Tobago and spend time sight seeing and enjoying local culture

Pigeon Point Heritage Park is a slice of paradise! The white sandy beaches and crystal clear waters make it the perfect spot for relaxation. The facilities are well maintained, and there are plenty of amenities including showers, changing rooms, and places to eat. The view from the jetty is breathtaking. A must visit for anyone traveling to Tobago!

Pigeon Point Heritage Park is a must-visit destination in Tobago. The stunning white sand beach, crystal-clear turquoise waters, and the iconic thatched-roof jetty create a picture-perfect setting. The park offers excellent facilities, including beach chairs, umbrellas, and a variety of water sports activities. The calm, shallow waters are ideal for swimming and snorkeling, and the reef just offshore is teeming with colorful marine life. Don't miss the opportunity to climb the jetty for breathtaking panoramic views of the coastline. Pigeon Point is a true slice of paradise that should not be missed during your visit to Tobago.

We visited Pigeon Point Beach on an excursion. It was hectic when we arrived because the distribution and placement of chairs was not organized. We were happy to find a spot under palm trees with a view of the water. The water was the most beautiful color and there were boat rides, ice cream, dressing rooms, basic bathrooms (bring toilet paper & hand sanitizer to be safe) and restaurants available. Expect to take a lot of photos because you will want to remember this view!

One of the most beautiful beaches I've ever seen! The powdery white sand and crystal clear turquoise waters were simply stunning. We spent hours relaxing on the beach and swimming in the calm sea. The entrance fee was very reasonable too. A must-visit in Tobago!
Dreamy Caribbean beach that you see in postcards. Visit the island if you can and feel like a castaway. Magnficent and probably our favourite Caribbean beach so far.

Pay an entry fee ($3 pp) to enter this beautiful, shallow, coastal beach. Great place to chill out for the day. You are given a wristband which I presume pays for the wash and changing facilities. There are various shacks selling beer, water, and food. You can also pay for the use of a lounger and/or umbrella, but there are also many shady trees and picnic tables. The large swimming area is cordoned off and is very shallow. Many boat trips and water activities start from this point.

What a fantastic beach, surrounded by beautiful park. Very clean,well maintained, with all facilities you need on the beach. The water is crystal clear. Sunbeds are 30TT pp . You can do all water sports there, be active or you can just relax, do nothing and just people watch for the whole day. This beach is for everyone,with a wow factor.
We enjoyed wonderful days of clean, serene, perfection. Perfect for families. Clean changing rooms and bathrooms and shower nice food options

Big tip. Go on the days when the cruise liners are not visiting the island. It costs TTD$20 per person to enter the area. We were disappointed with swimming at the beach as it shelves quite steeply and the entry to the water is quite stony. There is plenty of shade under the palms if you need it.

Remarkably blue waters, it‚Äôs paradise at Pigeon Point Tobago Pigeon Point is home to Tobago to the famous thatch-roof jetty, along with a amenities and activities, making it the perfect all-day beach destination. An entry fee of TT $20 (US $3) is required, granting visitors access to beach with the option to sample different restaurants, bars and shops; as well a variety of watersports:- swimming, snorkeling  and jet skiing

Another visit to Pigeon Point, and again it didn‚Äôt disappoint. Clean white sand and calm waters to spend the day relaxing. Just be careful of the steep drop into the water, however it is funny to watch as people struggle to get back out! If you fancy a little adventure when you‚Äôre there, hop on a boat trip and enjoy a beach barbecue at No Mans Land. All in all a fab day!

Had a great day here. Very well organised , very clean and plenty of space. We were the only cruise ship in that day and it is small(700 passengers) I can imagine that if a large ship docked then the beach would be overwhelmed, Apart from a few asking us if we wanted a boat tour as soon as we arrived, we were not troubled with people trying to sell things. Gorgeous setting
Beautiful beach with lots to do. Only issue was how much coral was in the water. It hurt to walk through. I'm used to a lot of shells and rocks being on the east coast but that was too much.

The Caribbean colors of this not very large beach are unforgettable. Once we disembarked from the ship, we reached it by private taxi before it was overrun by other cruise passengers, at a cost of $10 per person for a return trip. Entrance costs $3.50 per person and there is the possibility of renting sun loungers at a cost of $5 each. There are bars and services. I recommend the snorkeling trip at the cost of $30 per person to Buccoo Reef and Nyloon Pool.

Stopped in Tobago on a cruise. We were a group of 14. 6 adults & 8 kids. We wanted to stick together so as soon as we got off the cruise ship we asked for a taxi that would hold all of us. They quickly accommodated and we were in a taxi van almost immediately. Our taxi driver was named Elvis. He was wonderful. Very informative. He drove us to Pigeon Point Beach and left us with his card and asked us what time we wanted picked back up. He returned promptly at the time that we decided on and returned us to our cruise ship in plenty of time. Pigeon point beach was beautiful. The sand and water was like a postcard. A great day!

Greetings I went yesterday with my wife on a cruise. The people, the atmosphere and the Pigeon Point beach, lovely! The only negative thing; Transportation prices, seeing attractions, they even charge you more for the entrance to the beach. If you don't hire a taxi driver, you pay 70% upon arrival to ensure pickup, they charge you $40 per person to return to the ship. Much more compared to other islands. We don't have to go back to Tobago üáπüáπ

Beautiful beach with bars and gift shops with clean toilets /showers and beds and umbrellas for hire. The beach is also a pick-up point for the glass bottomed boats that take you to the nylon pool and buccoo beach trips which can be booked when you arrive. There are two times for pick up 11am and 2pm. Part of the beach is also a turtle nesting site, the far end has lots of water sports available, you simply need to walk past the taxi pick up point and past the swings on your left. Pigeon point is one of the busier beaches on the island, for a quieter time you need to travel a little further, there you will find many other beautiful beaches some with no one on them at all!
Amazing clean place and the sea sooooo blue and clear. You can do watersports which had a great choice. About ¬£2 to get in. Immensely glad we went

We went to this area "when" returning to the airport. to return to Portugal. And it was a surprise. Fabulous beaches with tourist support areas, including restaurants and toilets. Although it's not my style of place (I prefer beaches in areas with as few people as possible) the truth is that it's very good for those who like the "Jama" style.

My partner and I spent the majority of our time in Tobago at this beach. We purchased the 3 day couple Chillax package for $350TTD. This included 3 day entry for 2, 2 chairs and an umbrella. This worked out great for us because on our last day when we arrived an hour after the beach opened there were no more umbrellas and they compensated us by giving us one of the huts. The beach is beautifully picturesque, worth the iconic jetty. If you want to relax you can. If you‚Äôd like to take in any water sports that is available and o if you want to go on a glass bottom boat tour there is that option too. There are many well maintained washrooms & change areas. There are a few places too buy fits and drinks. However, it‚Äôs standard hot dogs/hamburgers and fries kind of food really. There are shops where you can buy snacks, souvenirs and anything beach worthy that you‚Äôve forgotten to pack. There is no soliciting other than the tour operators coming around to see if you‚Äôd like to go on a tour. Definitely a must when on the island.

First visit and not the last I hope. It was a big crush for me. Transportation to get there by taxi $25 round trip for both. Entry into the park is $3.50 per person and chairs $10 each. The water is just incredible and what can I say about the decor. The park is very clean and there are all the facilities on site. From the quay you can buy excursions for freediving or Nylon pool which we did not do this time.

We have been windsurfing at pigeon point for the last few weeks. You have to buy a day or month pass which is 20TT per day. Once there you can purchase chairs and umbrellas for 30 TT  for the day. There are a small amount of stalls which sell anything from clothes to inflatables. Two bars are in the area, one by the pier which plays loud music all day but serves food and drinks and this area is where all the cruise ship clients come and sit on the beach so it can get busy.. there is a area which is roped off for safe swimming as there are jet skis around.. DO NOT USE THE JET SKIS‚Ä¶ THEY ARE ILLEGAL AND CAUSE MAYHEM!!!!!!!!. From the pier you can get on a glass bottom boat from the pier but some are like disco boats which will probably scare any sea life away due to the thudding of the music. Further around the point is the Radical water sports centre which is where you can windsurf, paddle board etc.

Visited during a cruise, beautiful beach, possibility of renting umbrellas and deckchairs, if you arrive on a cruise I recommend going in the morning before it fills up with cruise passengers. Cost of entry into the area is 3.5$ (or ‚Ç¨), from the cruise terminal you can reach it at a cost of around 10/15$ each return (depends on the number of people, whether you take a car or minibus).
Stunning, beautiful beach.  Has good amenities - great to swim in - beautiful sand. 2 Lounge chairs & an umbrella rent for 120 TT a day.

Real nice beach but very crowded. Entry fee is 20TT . There is lots of food and drinks for reasonable prices.  Can take a boat to Nylon pools from here. Snorkeling isn't great but I've seen real reefs b4 so some might enjoy it.

This beach is beautiful and very clean.  The water is sparkling blue, there are washrooms, restaurants, bars, and rentals for chairs etc.  what more could you ask for?  It‚Äôs not huge, so everything is close by to access once you enter the park.  Entrance fee was $3.50 USD pp.  the sand is beautiful, and the swimming area is marked off from boats and jet skis.

I've read so many negative things about this spot that I can only think the reviewers are trying to save it for themselves!   We were a group of 4, hired a taxi to take us out and return to get us 3-4 hours later.  I'd say there was never more than 20 other people on the whole large beach while we were there.  Competing vendors selling (very good!) rum punch and other fruit based drinks.  One other vendor politely selling his jewelry.  The beach sand was soft, water was clear, temperature was perfect and it was slightly cloudy.  The only semi-negative is that it's a bit of a hike to the bathrooms from the beach.  We all truly enjoyed our day and thought this was one of the best days of our trip.  Go.  You won't regret it!
What you'd picture Caribbean Beach to be in your head. Fabulous day. Bobbed about in the sea, a few beers, crab & dumplings. Idyllic

A must go. We decided to go to this beach as Tobago was one of our port stops. We caught a taxi right outside of the port. The drive was about 25mins. There is a beach fee of approximately $3.50pp (USD). Once we were at the beach we were able to rent chairs and an umbrella. There were several amenities (showers & restrooms). The water was rough but cool. We ate at a restaurant on the beach and the food was delicious plus affordable. The restaurant played carribean music and was next to a pier. Overall great beach day for the family.

Nice busy beach, locals sale some souvenirs, women sale some local fruits, for sun beds need to pay. Safe beach, you can leave your stuff nobody touch it. Locals very friendly and helpful. You can got there local trips such as glass boat tour, or tour to Nylon Pools
Beach was nice a little rocky but very clean and the sight was lovely. Make sure to rent a chair and umbrella to enjoy the scenery.

This is a good beach to visit, plenty here bars shops, activities and places to eat can get busy so get early to get loungers/shade Although great beach there are better but we did still love spending the day here
A truly magical beach with attentive staff and good facilities. Get there early to enjoy the unspoilt beach and jetty with straw covered hut.

Visited this area a couple of times on our stay and thoroughly enjoyed it and would highly recommend a visit when in Tobago. The last day of our holidays we visited with other couples from our resort Happy Birthday Jerome, and just as we were leaving a guy said stay we are realising the baby turtles which was an amazing experience. Definitely worth a visit and to see the famous jetty.

Stunning, picture postcard beach. Really cheap entrance fee and day rental of loungers and parasols are also good value for a tourist spot. Decent facilities and a good bar near the pier to get a beer and have lunch.
Nice beach with great facilities. Toilets,lockers,and nice bar with food other bars but not open as quiet.Also several nice gift shops.You have to pay to enter beach but worth it.
Best beach in Tobago. Has bathroom facilities bars and restaurants. Beautiful calm tropical waters. You can rent cabanas. You have to pay to get into the beach.

Lovely beach with good facilities including small bars, food kiosks, washrooms and toilets, parking, etc.  20TTD pp entry fee as this is a heritage park area.  A good way to spend a day when in Tobago.

A free shuttle ride from our resort Sandy Point Beach Resort.  A very nice beach with lots of clean sandy shoreline. The water was nice and warm but not much for snorkelling. There where lots of little shops to browse and food vendors to to enjoy the delicious local cuisine. You can purchase beach chairs, umbrellas and cabanas for a very cheap price. Would revisit üëçüëç
I love TOBAGO. Pigeon Beach is beautiful! My husband and I enjoyed our day at the beach!  Relaying!!!

Pigeon Point is stunningly beautiful. It's like being in paradise.  But the whole experience is spoilt by the intolerable loud music coming from the bar at the furthest point of the beach. They also play the same tracks over, and over, and over. If you ask them to turn it down a little, you are likely to get attacked by the aggressively rude bar owner. It's a shame that the bar is allowed to spoil others' enjoyment of the beach.

Nice beach. When the wind kicks up you will get sand blasted. This was a cruise port tour. $5 for a beach chair. $5 for a beach umbrella. There are a few services available for food and drink. There are better beaches to visit if you are not constrained by a cruise tour.

This beach would be excellent for non-swimmers or those with toddlers as it is very shallow. Or those that just love to lay in the sun and get in for short dips. However, there was little to do for an avid snorkeling/ body surfing family. Get there early if you want an umbrella. They were sold out upon our arrival and everyone was huddling the chairs under trees.
Very upbeat  environment the people around are very friendly and there are little shakes along the way selling handcrafted jewelries

Perfect area for relaxing and sunbathing,also shopping and lunch (it‚Äôs closed at 5pm).Also snorkelling but there are terrible jet ski (stupid and irresponsible drivers transform a quiet area in a dangerous situation)You can find also restaurants and water sports and facilities.Absolutely well organised
Our favourite beach of all the 6 islands we visited. Wonderful beach, very well run, all prices displayed so no haggling . Good clean amenities, good choice of food
Free shuttle from our hotel, cost 20TT per person entry then 30TT per sunbed and brolly, great beach and swimming area well worth a visit,
If you‚Äôre visiting Tobago, this is a must.  Beautiful water, beautiful beach-great day at the beach.  Food and drinks also available.

Wonderful beach area. Loved the sand, and the restaurant on the beach had good drinks and food. Good place to find some coral stones if that's what you're looking for, but not much shells. Took a Glass Bottom Boat Tour from there and it was wonderful.
Nice beach. Not much else there to do bar sunbathe, special mention to the saxophonist in the bar next to the small pier, he was brilliant, didn‚Äôt get his name

We enjoyed our morning at Pigeon-Point. Fantastic beach, and the sea never came above my waist when wading out. Found a lovely bar right at the end of one of the beaches - actually playing proper rock instead of the interminable loud grungy beat "music" that we'd heard everywhere else!

Came to PP today and it was great. Beautiful beach lots of things to do like wind surfing or take a jet ski for a rip. There was a glass bottom boat tour run by captain dave we didn‚Äôt take cost was 240tt per person that seems reasonable. Would recommend anyone visiting to check this place out there was. 20tt charge per person We ate at Renmars had grilled fish it was delicious. Definitely recommend. Looking forward to more Tobago.

We are no longer as big a fan of Pigeon Point beach.  We use to be‚Ä¶and the beach is still beautiful.  The entrance fee has increased a bit ($20 TTD PP) which is not a problem considering the amenities and life guards on duty it‚Äôs seems very reasonable; but then you have to pay again for chairs ($30 TTD PP) OK‚Ä¶but now the gazebos are chained off and you need to call to arrange rental‚Ä¶it just too much. The last time we visited (years ago) we paid an entrance fee and then enjoyed a day at the beach.  The gazebos we available on a first come basis and folks were pleasant, relaxed and just enjoying the beach. It is now a business and a shame that a relaxing beach day is overshadowed by the tense business that now is Pigeon Point Beach.

It is a nice clean area with clear waters. I didn't spend time in the water because I was heading to the nylon pool. However, I saw both families and adults enjoying the beach and restaurants. There is a fee to be paid at the entrance.

Absolutely beautiful beach. Great for kids as well. White sands, turquoise water. Amazing place for sunset and picture taking. Shallow water with no waves, so ideal for families. Great snorkeling place.

Visitors to Pigeon local(seniors free) or foreign can expect a small entry fee . The white sandy beach with complimentary benches and shady trees , Concessionaires stands offer some variety of food /drinks.Other foods are not far away. There are no hustlers on the beach so visitors are not harassed to buy stuff .There are no junkies or peddlers of other stuff. Very relaxing clean beach.

Beautiful beach with great facilities. Buck the trend and go at the end of the day, as we do in Spain. Hardly anyone around, lifeguards gone home and the sun dipping on the horizon, really special. Last two hours of the day are the best two hours of the day.

One of the most beutiful beaches I have been to ever! water was so clear and sand was like powder. I have put July 21 but we actually visited around 10 year ago, we keep saying we are going back but not made it yet :(

Tobago is beautiful and not complete without a visit to Pidgeon Point and a trip on the glass bottom boat. The reef here is beautiful and some of the best snorkelling ü§ø Everyone is friendly. The stop off at no man‚Äôs land was brilliant with a chilled vibe and lots of delicious local street food available. Highly recommend this when you visit 10/10
Jetty is sadly not as iconic close up as it in in the promo photos.. Needs a  bit tlc, sadly like so much of Tobago, however Pigeon Point grounds and beach ARE cleaner than many

Absolutely stunning soft white sand beach.  Water is so warm.  You can float around without moving a muscle.  Lots to do or just soak up the atmosphere and beautiful weather.  Highly recommend a trip, or more, while in Tobago.
Didn't want to leave..... the water, the scenery and serenity, the food, the music the people . Loved It!

We stayed at the bungalow at Pigeon Point Airbnb. The place was surprisingly spacious, with a large dining/living room and the bedrooms were located at the far end, ensuring quiet sleep time and privacy. We could sit in our yard or cross the road to enjoy the gorgeous sunsets on an unpopulated stretch of beach. The walk to the main beach, which we enjoyed every day was a short distance and well worth the jaunt. It was a 10 minute walk down the road, where there was a bar and you could enjoy a beverage while overlooking the water. A few steps further and you could purchase traditional food for lunch or take it home for dinner from the little huts that are there. Continue walking on Pigeon Point Road to the roundabout and turn right. There are many restaurants with different cuisine to choose from. Our favourite was Debe Delights. You could get Doubles or Allo Pie for an equivalent of $1.00CAD. Keep going past Kodi‚Äôs Natural Treats, but stop at the next restaurant and say hello to Shelly. She makes a delicious jerk chicken, oxtail stew and bbq‚Äôd chicken, among other things. Don‚Äôt forget to order ‚ÄúFestivals‚Äù they are delicious.  It cannot go unsaid how our host, Ana, at the bungalow went above and beyond to make our stay comfortable. Although the accommodations could only be described as ‚Äútired and needing updated‚Äù Ana made every effort to upgrade items in the kitchen to make it more appealing. When we had trouble with out fridge, she had someone there to fix it as soon as she could. Also, the wifi didn‚Äôt work and although she could not fix it during our stay, she allowed us to use her wifi at the office, so that we could send messages to our families. Her warm greeting always welcomed us when we saw her. We would not hesitate to recommend this place, especially for someone who is not fussy and looking to be right on the most beautiful beach in Tobago.

Tobago is a beautiful place especially pigeon point beach. Definitely one of the top beaches I have ever been too. However the people of Tobago has a problem with a certain race of people from Trinidad. It's too bad that we have people that think like this. Like I said Tobago is beautiful but most of the people (not all) definitely has an racism problem.

I visited the beach after several years and was impressed with how developed the facilities were. I must commend the fact that bins are all over for persons to dump garbage and running water and soap were easily accessible given the Covid19 situation. The water was perfect and I swam for hours. Can't wait to visit again.

Recently went to pigeon point beach with the family while vacationing in Tobago the beach was breathtaking. The white sand, turquoise and teal waters with delicious local cuisine to choose from when lunchtime rolled around. The 1 downside was right after entry a guy approached the car and when we didn‚Äôt stop he banged on the vehicle very rudely stating we were disrespectful because we didn‚Äôt stop. He was touting his Nylon Pool boat service but he definite should be taught better customer service.
The beach was nice and clean but the food was absolutely disgusting.  Over $600 in food ended up in the trash.
Wind sports are great here.  You can windsurf, rent kayaks, learn to sail, and even kite.  If that sounds like too much work, just chill on the beach.

This is a private beach with beautiful white sand. Very scenic. The swells in the sea were very heavy so not compelling to take a dip. Chair and umbrella rental was seamless and efficient. The meal at the Bar/Restaurant of barbecue chicken, mashed potatoes and grilled vegetables was underwhelming. If I were to go back there I‚Äôd stick to having a drink or two and maybe order fries.

Best beach in tobago so much so I got married here Powder soft sand and clear waters, safe and secure lots of staff, lovely bars with great drinks and music, wait for food can sometimes be long. Has to be my favourite beach. Can get very busy when cruise ships come in.

column7: Port of Spain, Port-of-Spain, Trinidad and Tobago
column11: Beautiful beach with bars and huts where you can get food and snacks. There is also access to water sport activities. Lounge chars and umbrellas available. There is a charge to enter.

Amazing place to stay . Calm quiet peaceful. Rooms are in good condition with all facilities. 6 people can stay comfortably. Thankyou to Anastasia. She was amazing. She even got us a crib and a babysitter Recommend this place 5/5

We have enjoyed Pigeon point and the staff are friendly. The herataige park is well managed and peaceful. The bonus is Traditions bar and grill. Top food, vibe and location. The good thing is access to glass bottom boat rides at afordable prices.
Beautiful scenery and delicious food.  Something to do for everyone. (Sun tan, eat, drink, watersports)
I have to say this place has to be the most beautiful beach and well kept resorts in Tobago it was stunning this is my seat for the day.

An absolutely stunning beach, definitely worth visiting while on the island. There‚Äôs a small entrance fee per person as this is a nature reserve, but when you get inside you understand why. The whole area is clean and well kept and there are good facilities available (lockers, showers, loos, lifeguard) as well as food outlets and bars. Traditions serves great food, we had really yummy bake and shark and the rum punch was excellent! Glass bottom boat tours are available from about 100TT pp, but we negotiated a more private day-long tour with a great guy called Anton. For 500TT pp he took us on a coastline tour by speedboat. We snorkelled in 3 different places, including the famous Buccoo Reef. The coral and fish were incredible! We also visited the Nylon Pool, and had a delicious bbq lunch on the beach on No Man‚Äôs Island. Anton was fab and dropped us off at all these places just after all the party boats had departed so we had them all to ourselves! What an incredible experience, thank you Anton - find this guy on the beach and book him!
Pigeon point park very peaceful and clean.Great service and guide on the glass bottom boat. Local market was great.

Powder sand beach with lots of bars, restaurants and opportunities to sunbathe. A really beautiful beach with first-rate facilities, changing rooms, restaurants, bars, etc. A tropical paradise indeed.

When a beach is as well-managed as this one, you don't mind paying a small fee for the amenities. We had a wonderful time at this lovely beach - lots of lounges available for rental and ample space to spread out.
Warm gentle waters for a relaxing day on the beach. There are shops and bars/restaurants around also. Not over crowded. A safe place for a day trip.

I heard at times this beach is so crowded, but I didn't see that, at all.  There were people around, but it was very enjoyable.  We watched parasailing, whatever the word is when they are sailing on surf boards (lessons available).  Large area, with lots of activities.  Lots of shops, restaurants, and the beautiful jetty with the thatched roof for pictures.  Yes, it's the most commercialized beach we saw on Tobago, but sometimes, it's nice to have the amenities.

Beautiful, landscaped beach. Nice spot for some beach time or to watch the sunset. Several bars/grills available next to the beach. Facilities are in good condition and clean. We arrived around 5PM, where they did not charge the entrance fee anymore. To watch the sunset at Pigeon Point is a must if you visit Tobago. Especially on the bright day. It's just a 5 minute drive from Cown Point. Try the pub meals at Traditions, they are excellent.

We bought a pass to this beach where the water is nice and there are a lot of booths.  I was disappointed that there are not a lot of nicer quality items for sale, only cheap souveniers.  There is shade if you like it.  The bathrooms are clean, but you must buy a pass to use them.

A lovely place with emphasis on relaxation or at least it was. A bit too touristy these day which kind of spoiled the experience. New facilities too make it less authentic but comfortable for the visitor. Worth a day out, best time sunset. No need to worry as there are plenty of taxis in the area to take you back to your hotel.

This beach is one of my favourite places I visited in Tobago. Entrance into Pigeon point is 20 TTD. The different shades of aqua waters were a pleasure to watch & the iconic jetty (a great photo opportunity) You can hire 2 beds & umbrella for 90TTD. There is 2 main restaurants where you can purchase food & drinks. You are able to do boat trips to Nylon bay ( it is worth doing).

This beach is fabulous, but looked a little neglected this year. You have to pay to go on it, so come on clean the beach up of broken glass and seaweed. Renmars beach bar is fabulous for food and drink.
We are here 3 to 4 times per year, no matter how long our stay is, we are here on each day till sunset üòçüòçüòç

We took a taxi here from Black Rock and are so glad we did. We got there before the crowds and wandered to the right and around the bend - then back to the first bar for a drink. Went further down and dropped our stuff to enjoy the water - amazing colour and so fun in the swells. Very safe feeling - lockers and bathrooms available. We had a bite to eat and then we had to go, but could easily spend a whole day here!
Very safe and great facilities, palm trees ,sunbeds,shades and great water sports and cafes. A locals beach and tourist beach without any fuss

The entrance fee is moderate, a few TT dollars, and the beach is superb. Perfect sand and sea. You can rent comfortable loungers for $5 US a day, also a huge sun umbrella for the same price. So, you can admire the scene in full shade (if you wish) and great comfort.  If you arrive by car, you do best to drive as far as is possible, to the area where the loungers and 2/3 eateries are. Of course, you need a sunny day too, to appreciate the scene to its maximum advantage. When you venture for a swim you will find smooth white sand underneath. This is what gives the sea its magnificent turquoise colour.

Visited here last October,  whilst we were staying in Tobago.  Must say , the beach  is a perfect chill zone , especially during the week, that's when we  stayed for 3 days. 2 Cool beach bars , cabanas  to hire for larger groups, you can also catch a boat to the Nylon pool, a must if you visit Tobago. We will return
This is the ideal place to relax in the shade of trees on the beach, cool off with a swim and have a spot of lunch at one of the beach bars

Spent a day on Pigeon Point Beach. Loved it. The sand is like powder, the colour of the water is an incredible turquoise blue, there are great washroom facilities (all included in the park entrance fee), and great places to eat/drink. I HIGHLY recommend spending some time at Pigeon Point. You can also take glass-bottom boat tours from the pier out to the reef for snorkeling and to Nylon Pool and No Man‚Äôs Land. (We did that on a separate day and loved it.)
The beach is clean, sea is calm, lots of loungers and umbrellas for hire, eating places, good shower and toilet facilities. There is an entrance charge.
glass bottom boat - visit Buccoo Reef and Nylon Pool.  Very enjoyable.  Quieter experience than the 'party boats' with loud music on offer.
Beautiful beach safe swimming, good for wind surfing etc but does get busy when cruise ships are in Scarborough. Colours of the sea are amazing.

We spent more time here than I thought we would since we usually aren't into tourist beaches. Lovely beach and even better on the days the cruise ships do not port!  Many excursions can be done and booked here. Also watersport rental equipment available as well as some restaurants. It does have an entry fee to enter, but no fee to use the restrooms as some other areas do. I also felt the area to park seemed safer than at some of the other beaches.

Shallow water, can swim for hours here. 20TT to enter park and 30TT for sun lounger,300 TT for a hut. Can get glass bottomed boat here to experience nylon pool - 100TT per person (can negotiate with larger groups), Traditions restaurant on beach front does good bar food and fab photo opportunities all around. Well worth a visit but yes it‚Äôs not as unspoilt as it could be but it‚Äôs still super stunning place to be.

The beach where we were staying (Grafton) wasn't really suitable for relaxing, so took a taxi (TTD100 each way) to Pigeon Point for the day..... had visited briefly to catch the glass-bottom boat and Nylon Pool (amazing!) on a tour so knew it was lovely.  Didn't disappoint.... a small entrance fee (TTD20) provided a wristband, and a further TT30 a comfy sunbed wherever you wanted it .... plenty of choice of sunshine or shady trees & cabanas also available.  Lovely golden sand, clear water, well maintained toilets & a choice of restaurants.  Highly recommend at least one trip here when you're in Tobago.

We visited Pigeon Point with 2 Canadian couples who where guests of ours.  Unfortunately it was a Sunday and the place was packed with tourist from a Cruise Ship.  The water was amazing.  The problem is that there there was the risk of being run over by a jetski or a speeding pirogue.  The operators of these vessels seem to have no care or concern regarding swimmers. They fly pass so close to you its unbelievable and highly dangerous.  Pigeon Point needs to assign designated areas for swimming and Jet-skis just like that of Crown Point.  Don't wait for someone else to be seriously injured like the 2 persons in the past.

We spent the better part of the day here, arriving by taxi from Scarborough ($25 each way). It costs $3.50 ea. to enter the beach park.  It can get crowded in the main areas near the bars & restaurants.  But there are outer areas where you can escape to be alone. The food & drink is expensive for a beach place, e.g. $7US for a small rum punch in a plastic cup. And, the people serving the food & drink need to get educated in customer service.  There are shops too, but I could not find T-Shirts, only women's cloths. There were a couple bands playing when we were there. The beach & water is great. There is good snorkeling on the reef offshore. You can get a boat right from the beach to get to the reef.  But you need time, because once you are there, the boat stays there for quite a while.  So if you are on a schedule, inquire before committing to go. This is popular beach, so be prepared for people. I will include a photo.
The sand was so soft, No waves in the clear sea Lots of water sports avail or just relax and enjoy not very expensive to enter and the beer was reasonable as well
Excellent facilities, but very poor administration. The staff here needs to be trained in Customer Service and Courtesy.
Lovely spot although it does feel strange to pay to go in although it‚Äôs not expensive . Can get busy and noisy but you can get away to a quiet spot if you want

Lots happening all around.  Sometimes concerts go on and other times people are 'liming' at a few bars.  All types of boat tours happen from this area.  It's a good place to visit a few times while in Tobago.

Went here for the day. We were staying at Coco Beach Resort and walked to Pigeon point which is a good 20min walk - there are stalls along the way where people are selling drinks and snacks, so you won't get thirsty in the heat.    At the entrance you have to pay TDD20 per person and you get an armband.  If no one is around, you can just go through as the staff at the beach who will come and collect the entry fee and give you an arm band. Very nice beach with plenty of shade, you can also hire sunbeds for the day at TDD30 per bed(you pay at the ice cream shop, get a sunbed armband and then the staff bring you one). There are plenty of showers and toilets to use and also lock boxes if you want to store valuables.  We did not use one, but assume you can just ask the staff to rent one for the day. There are lots of places selling drinks, ice cream and food. The water is very calm and nice to swim in. We went on a Saturday and was expecting it too be busy, but it was not really.  All in all a nice relaxing day, and would definitely recommend.

After negotiating a reasonable price to go from the town to the beach we were pleased that our driver told us about the island and some of the important buildings. We had to pay a small entrance fee as Pigeon Point is a nature reserve, our driver had explained this first. He came back for us at the agreed time. There were water sports, but we walked further up to a quieter area. There were plenty of sunbeds ( which you had to pay for of course). We enjoyed watching the pelicans diving for fish. Plenty of restrooms, cleaner and better appointed than many I‚Äôve been to on beaches. No shortage of beach bars either and soft drinks were very reasonably priced.  It‚Äôs an idyllic spot, one of the highlights of our holiday.

Long Walk from the airport, or taking a Taxi or tour. Very clear water, different levels of wave activity, great for parasailing and windsurfing. Several options to see keys, islets or sand bars. Decent food Mut bonita playa, cerca del aeropuerto

Well maintained facilities in a beautiful surrounding. Lifeguards on duty, two bars/ basic grills on the beach (better options available in crown point town), souvenir shops and a place to rent water sports gear/ take lessons. The thatched hut is a great feature !
Quiet beach with beautiful views. I'd recommend checking it out as one of the better beaches in T&T.

Lots to do here, or just do nothing at all. A must if you are in Tobago. Very close to airport or if coming by Ferry to Scarborough a short 80tt taxi drive. The park has an entrance fee of $20tt not much cost for a piece of heaven.there are many different boats that take you out to the reef, nylon pool, and few other places. I founds you will save a boat load by just paying cash and book the boat ride when you arrive at pigeon Point. Mine was 80tt, well worth it. I would advise to avoid the few sketchy people that linger around the entrance of the pier trying to sell you drugs. I notice they mainly target folks walking alone.

Stayed at a small lodging on Old Store Bay Rd and walked to Pigeon Point. It is a flat, easy walk and takes about 20 minutes. There is fee to get in, but I didn't mind paying. It was small in comparison to beaches/parks where I live. (I won't get into too many details as they have already been said.) The water was beautiful and occasionally my foot did hit a piece of coral, but for the most part it was smooth sand. I wasn't bothered by too many vendors. A nice "no thank you" was all that was needed. There was a little ice cream stand that had some of the best ice cream. The bathrooms and changing rooms were very nice. Just be careful as the floors can get slippery.  A young boy did slip and busted his head open while I was there. It was nice to walk towards the end of park and watch the kite surfers. I enjoyed playing pool at the first bar/restaurant when I needed a break from the sun. I loved walking back right after sunset because along the road (in the park) I always got to encounter  hummingbirds at the flowering bushes. They would let you get so close. I imagine some of the people driving by thought i was a bit strange talking to bushes as they may not have seen the birds lol. Tips: If you comb the beach before and after the event pavilion, you can find lots of sea glass and beautiful shells. Very quiet along there too so great photo opportunities or if you need solitude.

Came here towards the end of the day to watch the sunset and have some food. Close to just about everything and crowds were not that big given the holiday week. Clean restrooms and wash/change facilities but you have to pay 2 TTD.

We just love this space. It‚Äôs seclusion makes it seem romantic and extra special. A very safe and serene place to be. A rich tradition being in this place swimming in this calm clear waters with its white sandy beach front.

This is a nature reserve, so you would expect the whole area to be clean and well preserved, which it is. Long sandy beach with plenty of bars and cafes. The sea is beautiful and very warm. A lovely place to visit.

I had a 22 hour layover in Trinidad i learned is not the place to be as a tourist. I booked a day trip to Tobago on Caribbean Air for $30 each way (same price for last minute too). Much less than cab fare between airport and Port of Spain and tourist focused. There is Store Bay which is closer to the airport and free. Pigeon Point is further out and has a small entrance fee. I decided on this since i figured its more relaxing. I was right and glad I made the decision. I'm a fairly quick walker even with my 20lb backpack. If it weren't for all the stops i took to look at things, i would have been about 30 minutes. Entrance fee was 20 TTD Locker rental was 30 TTD + 30 TTD deposit  (4PM was cut off for deposit refund) Chair rental was  30 TTD but it was partly cloudy so avoided the 30 TTB umbrella rental There is a restaurant and bar right next to the beach. Beers were 15 TTB + various cocktails for a bit more. There was also full menu available. I did BBQ chicken and sides for take away 55 TTB. It wasn't too crowded at the beach which was what I wanted. Only one guy tried to sell his aloe plants to me on the walk in but never saw him again. Later that day one guy tried to sell a tour but he left me alone after i told him I was just there for the day. The water was calm and enjoyable just to float around. There was a small hump to get fully in that had some coral and shells but it wasn't too bad. I wish i could have spent more time there.

A really beautiful beach with excellent facilities, changing rooms, restaurants, bars etc, but they don‚Äôt intrude on the beauty of the place, palm trees, azure and turquoise waters and white gold sand. A must to visit - tropical paradise.

We got a free shuttle from the hotel and were pleasantly surprised  by how beautiful it is . We were met by  a local guy Anton who for $20 took us on a tour in his glass bottom boat to buccoo reef and nylon pool alsi a brif stop on no mans land. Well worth $20 as the hotel is offering this at $90 each !!! We met an amazing local guy called Ellis who dpes tours ellistours He talked us through what we wanted to do and we put together a personalised tour of the island which was absolutely amazing! We visited tiny little coves and beaches the Humingbird sanctuary and had a boat trip to the pink beach with a legend of a guy called Sonson , we Snorkeled And had a beautiful chicken lunch on a deserted beach with a lush arainforest backdrop.  Highly recommend a tour with ellistours This was a beautiful day out with a really nice guy . Thanks ellis üòé
Lovely beach and park it has a few bars and restaurants you have to pay to get in but it is worth it as you can make a day of it
Well worth taking this walk up the road from Store Bay, with a couple of nice local restaurants with good lunch offerings.
A safe place for people who feel nervous on their own. To many people for my liking, too much like an all inclusive resort. I prefer a wild beach without the crowd.
had a great half day on the beach--fabulous views and so peaceful--totally free so why not ? and the sunshine

The best beach in Trinidad or Tobago. A 10 min drive from the airport , a small fee to enter , and you have beautiful white sands and clear warm water. All the usual beach facilities around ... changing rooms, toilets , lockers, Resturant, bars , a few vendors selling souvenirs, and on the far end ... all the water sport activities. An additional fee for the use of beach chairs or huts , but picnic benches are free and scattered around the area. No one bothers you to buy anything on the beach , and security guards and life guards are on duty.
In my opinion this is the best beach in Tobago............... lovely landscaping and the water is calm and clean
Went there just on off chance beautiful beach , gardens,nice bar called traditionals good food drinks at good price.Nice safe swim area well worth a vist

The Park is now charging for huts.....if so they need to be looking much better than wat my eyes behold yesterday. You can't be charging so much for those huts yet there are in such deployable condition.....the wiring cur,the beaches breaking off and the need for some paint.  The washroom are broken and looked up please if you are in the tourism business you need to look and smell that way.... concern citizen
It was a good experience. Beautiful clear water and white sand. Just a shame it rained most of the day.

TT60 per person for the day. Nice beach, well kept grounds. Shower and toilet facilities available. Picnic benches free to use. Beach huts are costed according to size. No snorkeling and swimming area roped off to safeguard from motorised water sports. You get a wristband, different colour each day and there are people checking you have paid to enter. Radical sports offer a variety of water activities. Huge ‚Äúsculpture‚Äù of a wired fish filled with plastic bottles. Very expensive tourist shops. Ice cream and food, prices not checked. Pretty area, arguably best beach in Tobago. Walkable from Store Bay if cool.
I did not swim at this beach or see this beach in the day time but I partied at this beach from night until morning during great fete weekend and I had an amazing time!

Pigeon Point is a protected area and it costs 20 tt dollars to enter. The beach is golden and the sea is blue. Sun loungers are available for a small charge. There is a good bar serving food and some shops. It is also possible to take a boat ride to visit the nylon pool.  Refreshments available from 1130
Had the greatest time! Swimming, snorkeling, boat trips. Lockers and chair hire definitely a plus... as always the locals are amazing. Traditions beach bar make the BEST Bloody Marys!!

It costs 20TT (Trinidad & Tobago Dollars) - for us less than ¬£3 each. This includes use of shower and toilet blocks (very clean). The water is warm and clear but you do have to pay 30TT$ if you want a sunbed. Ice creams great value but drinks at the bar were expensive for the island. Loads of water sports bookable and a Glass bottomed boat tour.

Visiting fron Florida and had an awesome time. At this beach. It was not crowded on the week lots of things to do. Including jet ski. And taking the glass boat out on the water. Lots of food vendors to choose from food was nice and hot. And music from 2 different restaurant. We enjoyed. Fried fish, stew beans,mac and cheese pie, fried rice and plantains for tt$70 It was good.will be back in February.

Great beach. Nice clean facilities and good food/drink options. Spoiled slightly by a few rude sellers who would simply stabd in front of you without saying a word and when you asked/looked up said "im selling" (what exactly was never clear) when we said no thanks stormed off or told us we were rude haha.

The photos of the beach speak for themselves but to emphasize: the water is usually very calm and the beach well maintained. There's a bar and restaurant on the beach, as well as little kiosks to purchase swim wear and souvenirs. There is an entrance fee of TTD 20.00 for adults. This is valid for one day, so you can go back and forth from the compound.
Fantastic day on the beach. Beds and umbrellas can be hired at a reasonable price. Charge of 20tt to get in do take some money for this. Food also reasonably priced

After going out to the Nylon pool we spent a couple of hours at Pigeon Point.  There is a minimal entrance fee because it is a national park.  We swam and had a relaxing  time,   The beach is quite large with  lounge chairs for rental, a few boutique shops and some refreshments for sale.

What can we say.  I nearly cried when we drove into the  beautiful area. Tall palm trees, white sand and turquoise sea.  Breathtaking. Very clean. Wonderful atmosphere.   Lots of wash rooms. You can rent a sun bed for few pounds. Lots of restaurants and a few shops.

Pigeon Point was busy, crowded and the water quality showed it. The water was murky and filled with lots of seaweed. If you enjoy a lot of facilities this is a beach for you. There are shops, restaurants, showers, bathrooms and activities. Note- they are very serious about one customer per paid chair!

Got a cab up just after opening was quite but as the day went on was busy so not as attractive to me Everthing was clean with several members of staff about had a bite to eat reasonable priced didn't mind paying entrance and subbed hire if it goes to up keep nice to swim in sea nice and calm done it got tee shirt sort of place for me but worth a visit

Pigeon point heritage park houses the wonderful pigeon point beach. There is a cost to enter this area. It is worth it. I think it is $20 for adults and $10 for kids. Senior citizens over 65 are free. I love the white soft sand. I have found that the water over the years changes colour from blue to green. It was green this year. I love renting a hut for the day and chilling out. The downside are the "touters", the seaweed, sand flies and crowds. I understand the crowds because it is the most popular beach in Tobago. A true must see and sea dip.

I have always recommended to visitors coming to Tobago spend at least 1 day at Pigeon Point. Go early grab a beach hut, food, drinks water sports, sun beds all available. I was very upset when some tourists cane back to me and told me that you now have to pay for the beach huts. I checked the web site ... beach huts free.... I entered into a discussion with Pigeon Point and I was informed that you now have to pay for the huts. I informed them that the correct procedure in such matters would have been to amend the web site then place the charge. The web site was amended Having a group of people here I decided to rent one of the huts for the day.... and truthfully it was quite disgusting. The same tired huts that were free are now being charged for.. with the same broken trellis work round it... the same huts severely needing a bit of tlc. You pay a very small entrance fee to the park supposedly for the upkeep and the facilities. The toilets were absolutely filthy. My suggestion the money you are charging for the huts buy some paint and give them an upgrade, maybe consider increasing your entrance fee and employ attendants to ensure toilet facilities are clean
Excellent beach to go swimming and kayaking. The beautiful clear waters are irresistible. I enjoyed my first time kayaking and met lots interesting people.

It is reasonably well kept and you can get beach chairs and brollies as well as various food options. There are also some tourist boutiques at one end and of course, there is the iconic jetty. The water quality in the main beach leaves a lot to be desired however, with old seaweed (the weed has sunk to the bottom and has been trampled into a fine swill) all over the place. The water in the area around the corner, beyond the breakwater, is of better quality.  There is also an area beyond the main baech that have basically become a boat repair yard and graveyard, quite unsightly.

What a beautiful day my famiy and I had when we went to Pigeon point for the day. It's a paid beach to get into. I paind $20 and my kids were $10 each so not too bad. We took a taxi in from where we staying in Bucco. $50 for pick up and drop of. The beach was nice and clean. Waters were clear, a little rough the day went and a lot o sea moss but otherwise beautiful sight and breath taking. We weren't hassel at all to do any water activity. You had to pay for your umbrella and beach chais, which is kind of a necessity. Food and drinks available for purchase. All and all it was agreat experience. I would definitely go back. Next year actually when I return for carnival.
Very clean beach with necessary facilities close by. The restaurants serve delicious foods as well. Water sports are redily available as well.

What can I say about the famous pigeon point beach you've not already read ?? White soft sand.. warm water . Plenty of food places to expand your tastes and waist band.   Cold beers and cocktails a plenty. Ice cream and sodas also.  Watersports and tours on glass bottom boats.  Trinkets, towels and souvenirs. It's a wonderful, vibrant place at the weekends and a quieter more peaceful visit weekdays.  Enjoy.

Pigeon point, one of Tobago‚Äôs iconic landmarks, there is no doubt in my mind that this is one of the most beautiful places in the world, what visitors don‚Äôt know is that Pigeon Point isn‚Äôt the jetty with the massive selfie frame, it is the point just beyond where the palm tree points out towards the crystal clear Caribbean ocean. We went on the glass bottom boat aptly named Sugar Lips and captained by the lovely Romeo (I kid you not the captain was Romeo on the Sugar Lips boat) we snorkelled on Boccu Reef, swam in the nylon pool and went to no mans land ( a thoroughly enjoyable day)
Blue waters, white sand, well kept, secure and full of vibes, definitely a must visit when you're in Tobago!!

This has to be on elf the most beautiful beaches I have ever seen with pure white sand and turquoise water. We visited on a weekday in June and there were hardly any people there. This is a must see if you are in Tobago
Always great. One of the best beaches on the island. We got married here and so we always come back.
Tobago has some of the best beaches in the world. This beach is so calm and peaceful that it will melt away all your problems! I recommend that anyone visiting Tobago to go here
Gorgeous turquoise calm waters beckons one for a lesuirely dip that you can't get enough of Lovely beach garden

This is one of the best beaches on the island. So it's really popular and can get packed over the weekend or on public holidays. It's best to go during the week when it's far less crowded and a lot quieter. You also do have to pay to enter; but the views are worth it!
Pigeon point was beautiful. The place was clean and the people were friendly. We only stopped by on the tour boat but the time we spent there was wonderful.

This is the white sand, turquoise beach the Caribbean is known for.  Its just gorgeous but we found a lot of rowdiness while there for a few days. One day there were a group of men using very vulgar and obscene language and as the day progressed, they got extremely drunk and loud. Several families moved away from them, but not once did security approach them.  The next day, some teenagers snuck in a were playing a loud game of aqua basketball for a while until someone finally noticed and took them out.  The patrons at the bar were also extremely drunk as the day progressed.  It seems with all the drinking, no wonder we found several carib bottles in the water. As much as I love the water and its great for youngsters, security needs to do a better job of keeping things quiet and orderly in this family friendly beach. This combined with the high level of solicitations by the glass bottom boat peddlers can be excessive, beware as they flag you down as you enter the beach.  If this was a free public beach, it would be fine but you pay to come here and improvements are warranted.

Definitely worth the entrance fee . It's a picture postcard beach with white sands and turquoise water . Get there when it opens to avoid crowds . Really noisy beach bar by the pier which is not in keeping with the setting . Take a boat trip to Nylon pool . Can recommend kassim if you want a quieter tour . Definitely a must see .
This is a lovely spot with a good choice of bars and restaurants, the sea is clear and the sand is white
Great place to see a nice beach. A little overcrowded and developed with space on the beach hard to come by.
Clean beach and have lots of water activities. Food stall on far side takes a really long time to serve however...It took over 30 mins for some fried chicken. Bar is cool...Lovely owners.

Visited here whilst waiting for a boat tour. Plenty of shade and souvenir shops. Good bars (recommend Traditions). Always people trying to get you to go into their boat. Sea not great - stones and seaweed, water fairly clear but not crystal. Better beaches around - this one recommended probably because you can get to Nylon Pool from here.

We spent several of our days in Tobago at pigeon point as the beaches are white and the water is clear, making it one of the best on the island. It is 20tt each to get in, so make sure you‚Äôre aware of this before you go. We walked along the beach before you get to the main entrance to the park and this is beautiful and secluded.

With turquoise, almost crystal clear water, this beach is ideal for all‚Äîchildren, the elderly and adults alike‚Äîalmost no waves. There‚Äôs a 20 TTD entrance fee which covers unlimited use of the toilet facilities. Persons ages 65+ are free. You also have access to the various shops, restaurants/bars and water sport rentals. Chairs are available for rent as well. You can also get the glass-bottom boats that goes to the Nylon pool from here. Just be careful, sometimes the guys pester and overcharge you. Lifeguards are on duty. The best time to go though is during the week when here are no crowds.
There‚Äôs a history that can be taught of when you hear of these beaches but nothing beats experience; I get to call this home and for that I‚Äôm grateful.
Loved this beach so much. Very clean, crystal clear water. No sharp stones to step on. Plenty of clean bathrooms and showers...also tons of nice shops and restaurants all reasonably priced

Pigeon Point Park is in crown point and a short walk or drive from downtown.  There is an entrance fee sometimes of about 20ttd but it is well worth it.  There are multiple bars and shops here as well as restaurants.  Change room and washroom  facilities are kept spotless and there are lifegaurds and security on duty.  The beach is adjacent to the Buccoo Reef and Lagoon and is perfect for spending the day on the beach or swimming in the waters.

It was nice to get away from the seaweed and rough waters of the Atlantic side and to be able to swim in the warm clear waters of the Caribbean.  A visit to Pigeon Point should be high on anyone's to do list.
From the scenic drive into Pigeon Point,to the well kept grounds, Pigeon Point should be a definite visit

Came to the beach today and it did not disappoint, warm, clean sand, pristine water.. lovely! We were approached by a couple of glass bottomed boat operators who were very polite not pushy at all! However my relaxation was hampered by the fact that I (and others) do not have a beach chair. Chairs, hammocks, umbrellas are clearly advertised for rent, yet no one available to get the products from. When I approached the staff about when they would be ‚Äúopen‚Äù for business, the gal said ‚ÄúNow‚Äù which was 1/2 hr agoüò¨. Having been to Tobago a number of times, I appreciate the locals are on ‚ÄúTobago‚Äù time (add 1/2 hr to any time!), but this is a tourist spot, advertising products and prices - that should be available when they say they will. Good customer service is also part of the experience... and I‚Äôm still waiting for my chair.
Wonderful beach on both sides, a couple restaraunts on the beach, the food is overpriced but the beer and drinks are reasonable. lovely spot to catch some sun and go for a swim.
BBQ Food on the beach is fantastic. the best beach in Tobago. Any sports you want to do. Quiet overall. Police presence is a plus.
This beach location provides beautiful views of clear waters, relaxation, and all necessary amenities. There are activities for persons of all ages and skill levels.

An absolutely beautiful place.  Our hotel on Tobago was just awful (review to come when I've calmed down!) but they did provide a free shuttle bus to Pigeon Point to which we escaped many times on our trip to Tobago, often taking a picnic with us.  It is stunning with powder white sands and all the facilities you could wish for.  There is a small entrance fee to pay and sunbeds for hire.  The rules and regs here are quite strict but are respected by all visitors and it is litter free and very tidy.  The beach to the right is lovely but if you turn left to the turtle nesting side (not laying during our visit) but no sunbeds for hire you find the sands even more incredible and you can walk all the way along the beach to chat with the local fishermen and see the antics of many pelicans crammed on the boats! The sea is crystal clear but not much to see if you snorkel.  The whole area has a very beach party atmosphere but never intrusive if you want some peace and quiet.  The weather during our stay was exceptional and it was lovely to sit and watch everyone, young and old alike enjoying themselves. I took loads of photos and on showing them to friends back home they assumed I'd snapped pictures of postcards!  It really is a beautiful place.

What can I say?  The beach was pristine white soft sand and due to the horseshoe shaped reef that completely surrounds it, the sea is completely calm and very safe for all activities.  We took a glass bottomed boat trip and went swimming and snorkelling and at one point could stand up in the middle of the sea! There are a choice of operator including one that offers loud music (not for us!) and there are also a choice of shops and bars - but you don't have to go far to find peace and tranquility.  There is a water sports activity outlet which was disappointing in that in terms of sailing, it only offered catamarans and not dinghies. Overall, it was a wonderful place and one of the highlights of our holiday.

We visited Pigeon Point Beach at the end of March, 2019.  It is very Sandy with an easy ocean access.  We would recommend this beach for sun bathing, swimming, or taking a  snorkeling charter from Zoe Snorkeling Charters.

Spent the day here on a cruise excursion. The beach is beautiful and the sea was lovely and warm and clear. Had lovely food and drinks at the bar. The people were great and very friendly. It felt very relaxed and safe with great toilet facilities. We had the best day would definitely return.

Pigeon Point is a beautiful beach with white sand and turquoise waters and lots of options to either chill or be active.  There is a roped off swimming area with no waves, so safe for all ages -- also includes lifeguards.  Beach chairs available.  There is a beach restaurant with good selection of drinks and food.  The area also has an area with souvenirs and beachware.  There are plenty of picnic tables and shelters to have a picnic lunch.  Nice bathroom/shower facitlities as well.  If you are going for an active beach day, the area also has a full watersports facility where you can rent windsurfing, kitesailing equipment and jetskis.  Also can go on glass bottom boat tours to Nylon Pool if that is your thing.  (The people selling the tours were prevalent, but not super pushy).  Definitely worth spending a beach day there!

I absolutely love this beach! We have a vacation home in Tobago and I am there 3 times a year or more - each trip I devote at least 1 day to Pigeon Point. Sometimes there is a lot of seaweed in the water and this is the only thing I do not like, but this will not stop me from returning. The food and drinks at Traditions Bar and Grill are excellent!! Had a mahi mahi fish today there that would rival any fine dining restaurant!! In the past I have enjoyed many other meals there

There is an entry fee to Pigeon Point of 20TT per person (about ¬£2.50 at the time of our visit). The beach is of fine white sand with a fringe of palm and other trees. The drive in is through a well manicured and beautiful lush park. There are bars and restaurants beside the beach and an array of tourist type cabanas. There are plenty of pub style benches to sit on, loungers for hire or shelters where people were eating picnics brought with them. The water was as clear as this Trip Advisor photo shows. Food and drink prices with in the gates were reasonable. A must for beach lovers.
Always a good idea! It's never a bad time to take in the calm and beauty of Pigeon Point, Tobago.  A must!

The beach and coral sands are exquisite. The colours of the sea beguile and hypnotise with the turquoises, greens and blues. Seeing hundreds of blue crabs scurrying for cover was astonishing. Unforgettable experience.
Apart from the beach and few restsurants, there are a lot of activities that can be done at this beach. From wind-surfing to para-sailing and jetski. Also you can board a reef tour to "no mans land".

Crystal clear turquoise blue waters clean friendly environment shark & bake lobster anyway you want it. Take a trip on a glass bottom boat to Buccoo Reef snorkel amongst the colourful species of fish and coral then swim in the nylon pool stop off at No Mans land for King fish meal Truly magical ...a must visit
It costs 20TT dollars per person to enter. There are places to eat, shops. Changing rooms. Pleasant to visit and swim . The pier out into the sea is famous.

To be fair, the entryway and gardens make for a spectacular view. Full of fountains and man made waterfalls, good grounds keeping that would make a golf course jealous, and cute shops, a full bar and restaurant, plus sports shop make it convenient for a family to visit. But from entry (20TT per adult just to enter) to parking your car, expect to be hounded by Frankie's Tour Boat company salesmen, who every five feet, will ask you if you want to buy tickets to see the nylon pools. On top of that, we find out later that they are ripping off tourists by selling 75TT tickets for 100TT (just over $10). Not a lot of money to get mad about, but still annoying. You can purchase those tickets for the regular, fair price at the Store Bay ticket booth. In addition, the "safe swim area" is very restricted. Don't expect the swimmable area to be more than 5ft deep on a high tide day. Additionally, you have jet skiers, windsurfers and kite surfers, plus the occasional Frankie tour boats sharing one small area. Food was mediocre at best. You want a better beach, go to Store Bay. And it's free.

Pigeon Point is probably the best beach in Tobago to spend the day. The $20 TT admission plus $30TT for our chairs was very reasonable. The water was lovely, cool no real waves. We went through the week so it was not too crowded. There is a section of the beach further down where the wind surfers can rent boards. On our walk down the beach we could see them out on the sea zipping around. We had lunch while there. They have all the usual, burgers, chicken but we decided to have the flying fish. It was delicious and then we finished off with  pineapple coconut ice cream. And a Carib bear. A great day. We went back 3 more times while we were in Tobago and had a great day each time.

The beach is picturesque.  There are shower, toilet facilites lining the beach.  Restaurants on site, ice cream sold on site, bar on site.  It's ideal to spend a day.  You get the glass bottom boats right on the beach as well.  There is free WiFi.  Cost to enter the area is $20TT ($3US) for adults, half price for kids and free for kids 5 and under.  We were able to rent chairs and unbrellas for $30TT ($4:50 US) each.  You won't regret the visit to this beach.  Water is calm and safe for the young ones.  Nice powdery sand.  Go enjoy.

We went back 3 times we loved it that much.
