Go nice and early and get your sun bed in the best position only $60 for two. $20 entrance fee each but you have plenty of wooden benches for free and lots of really clean toilets and showers to clean off in after your day at the beach. Lovely sea to swim in on one side of the point and on the other an adventure beach with  kite surfing and all sorts of water activites which made for a great viewing of other peoples great skills. Fab place loved it.

Pigeon Point Beach was a great place to visit. It was clean and beautiful. The washrooms were good, and the restaurant we tried had good food and it was priced quite reasonably. The entry fee was well worth the visit.

Lunch at Pigeon point was decent and the cocktails were pretty good. The beach itself was the most touristy spot we visited in Tobago. However, by walking just a minute to the other side of the pier we arrived at a completely empty and beautiful stretch of beach where we found a perfect spot to hang out below a small palm. A bit further down, you aren't allowed to swim (it's protected) so you can see some really cool shells, small marine life, and pristine beach front!
This one has been on my bucket list for years. I have rarely seen a better beach and I have never seen a green ocean like this one. Wow.
Lovely beach and relaxed beach day. Sand very soft and easy to access water. I wore beach shoes as I don‚Äôt like walking on bits of coral and rocks. Lotsa a good and drinks available
Fabulous beach.  Lots of stuff to do, places to eat and drink, great trips to Nylon Pool and Bucco Reef.  Pay for deck chairs and put them under one of the trees for a fab relaxing day

Really great beach, some larger rock areas and cordoned off areas for safety from boats and Jet Skis. Easily a day can be spent here. 20TTD to get in, mostly used to keep areas clean but did find some litter, overall a very good and we think best beach in Tobago.

Spotless beaches with safe swimming in the ice-blue Caribbean plus loads of clean loos and wash rooms. Bars, food, in fact everything you could need for a great day at the beach. Sun loungers only 30TT's each for the day so not going to break the bank. Wonderful relaxing spot and plenty of room for all. Look out for Barry on the beach - he might look a bit iffy but trust me, he provides brilliant boat trips at very sensible money. Ask for Captain Conda - he'll take you to all the little coves, bays and beaches and will tell you all the best snorkelling places. You might also catch a tuna for your lunch - we did!

This is probably the best beach area in Tobago but, like most of this wonderful island, it‚Äôs not promoted at all well. You pay a 20TT dollar entry fee and progress up an avenue of palm trees, the beach is divided into two areas , one for swimming and one for water sports. The views a classically Caribbean, there are bats , restaurants and several shops. There‚Äôs a jetty for glass bottom boat and snorkelling trips. You could spend the day here very easily.

Lovely time with my friends who were visiting the island for their first time. Enjoyed the rum punch, beach a friendliness of the locals. Though the beach still had a bit of seaweed, the water was still beautiful.

Well worth the small entrance fee.  Washing facilities, a few shops, bar, snacks.Ice cream,  shade, wonderful sandy beach with clear water and plenty of offers for jet skis, wind surfing etc..  really enjoyed our time here, especially the glass bottom boat trip with snorkling and swimming.  Most hotels seem to offer a free shuttle service to allow a full day.

Pigeon Point is a beautiful sandy beach.  There is a small entrance fee $3 - $4 US which pays for upkeep.  The only thing I didn't like is being approached repeatedly by sales people trying to get you to buy their tours. Be prepared, if you want a lounge chair you have to pay for it.

Pigeon Point is a must do when you‚Äôre visiting Tobago. This was my second time visiting with the last time in 2005. There have been vast improvements with the property since we were there last. There are showers & clean washrooms. There are chairs to rent though we found an available picnic table and sat there for free. There are people trying to sell you glass bottom boat tours and jet ski rides. They left you alone after you declined. We took a taxi from our hotel though you could walk there as there is trees to provide shade. The admission was 60 TT for our family of 4. The taxi ride from the hotel was 60TT and the return was 50TT. The return price was posted at Pigeon Pt.

Beautiful place. Great for everyone. Facilities such as 2 bars, toilet and changing blocks, lockers, sun beds and boat trips. (Read my review on Trip advisor about the Nylon pool). Entrance fee is 20TT$ per day but you can buy weekly passes for 100TT$. There are security people who check that you have a wrist band. These can be bought from the entrance to the park or from the kiosks. Felt very safe here. Use TT$ in Tobago and not US$ as the prices are better value in their own currency. If you're into water sports then check out Radical sports.

We have visited Tobago many times and always make Pigeon Point part of our trip. It is an archetypal Caribbean beach with white coral sand and smooth blue waters. In addition it has plenty of beach huts, washing and changing facilities, bars, food outlets and beach shops. Windsurfing and kayaking is also on offer at the far end of the beach. There is an entrance fee to use the beach and its facilities but an adult full price ticket is only 20$ TT which converts to ¬£2.20p, a ridiculously small cost for the beauty of the place and use of all its facilities. There are additional charges for beach recliners, like every other beach I‚Äôve been to, but these are also minimal at 30$ TT for the whole day. We visited as a group of 9 adults and as is usual on our visits to Pigeon Point we had a wonderful day. We will be going back there again!

Beautiful white sand and cristal clear water. The best part is in the reserve and you must pay an entrance and then, if you want a su bed, another ticket for that. We found it all very worth it. There‚Äôs are restaurants and bars and also places for water sports.

Drove down to pigeon point, have to pay $2 each to get in. A park area of grass and palms before you arrive at the white beach.  Lots of activities going on wind surf, kite surf and cat sailing. Lots of picnic areas under shade. A couple of place to get basic food eg burgers etc and drinks. Well worth a visit.  We spent the whole day there

A modest fee gets you into this fabulous resort area. Plenty of on-site parking. It offers a sandy beach on which to sunbathe, protected water for safe swimming and lots of shady areas into which you can retreat. There are plenty of bars and restaurants to serve all you're likely to need by way of food and drink. Sun loungers and parasols are available to hire for the day. For the more adventurous there are windsurfing and kite surfing facilities available. you can also try your hand at paddle boarding with Duane, an instructor who comes highly recommended.
Must visit place to see beautiful sunsets. Clean beach, option to buy good food. Free  and safe parking. Small entry fee.
Pigeon Point is a protected park. A haven on a headland with some great flat water sailing. There‚Äôs an interesting reef a mile off shore for the adventurous.

We visited here a couple  of times during our stay at crown point. It has a beautiful beach and many amenities...toilets...showers...bars...snacks...meals...drinks. You can hire sunbeds if your wish. Many boats go out to buccoo reef.....I‚Äôm afraid some are far too noisy.....why do you want that in such an idyllic place. I can sit back at the hotel and drink rum if I want to? Just to mentio.....DO NOT book the reef trip with ocean 1.......he took our money ..took us to the reef and then to the nylon pool...all lovely. But then on to no mans land as the others on board were staying for a bbq.....he knew we didn‚Äôt wish to stay and had booked our taxi Back to the hotel, but refused to take us back...saying we had to go back on frankies  boat (the one with loud music) and we said no! Then insisted we go back on the sugar lips boat...which we had no choice but  to accept.....and that was fine. But we should not have been treated like this......why didn‚Äôt he just let us book with another company.......an  absolute disgrace......all the other tobagonians we met were very nice......unfortunately he was a liar......and then you begin who to trust? It also gets very busy on cruise ship days....but fortunately I had checked  the schedules .....people told me ther wasn‚Äôt a bed left when the ship was in....but we had acres of space when we visited. Well worth the visit and the entry fee of 20ttd (¬£2.50) taxis take you right up to the beach area!

there is beauty surrounding you on the island of tobago - all free to look at as you wend your way around.  beautiful coves and beaches.  pigeon point is very beautiful, but certainly not moreso than others on the island.  it is a beautiful clean beach, but the price of admission to the grounds is a bit off-putting.

A day at the beach from 10 AM to 4 PM was a bit long for us but that was the time our driver was picking us up. we had lunch at a buffet restaurant but I can't remember the name --it was a long name , anyway the food was wonderful and you had lots of choices.  You can rent a lounge chair for $5 US or $30Trini money

The only other beach area that can touch this is Englishman's Bay. Pigeons Point is well worth the T$20 entry fee ( about ¬£2 a person) Loads of bars and eateries and places to chill out. Ice cream available and an excellent pier to lounge on and see all the fish and the pelicans. Just be aware of the prices differences in the touristy shops. Don't buy anything until you have visited them all. Some will try and charge you triple the going rate and what others charge

A must see place on Tobago but in danger of being spoiled.The boats play really loud music which in my view is inappropriate for such a lovely area.On our visit,there was only one bar/restaurant open.We waited an hour for a very poor meal.Take your own food.

Amazing beach and clear water. One suggestion I would make is that the authorities stop people going into the water,  with glass beer or pop bottles...that could be abandoned in the water and which could cut a swimmer very badly
Oh my gosh. This is a must see place. Water is crystal clear. Lots of little shops and places to eat. It‚Äôs a piece of heaven.

We were coming in for the day off a cruise ship. We did the Buccoo reef tour with a swim in Nylon pool and then stopped at Pigeon Point for a few hours. The beach is very clean and their are plenty of solid places to eat and grab a few adult beverages.

column7: The Royal Town of Sutton Coldfield, UK
column11: Stayed at Crown Point and visited a couple of times. Walk takes approx 40 minutes which we enjoyed with the local sights en route, returned by taxi. The whole complex is within a Heritage Park. You pay TTS20 entrance fee each (just over ¬£2) at barrier which covers the whole day. Taxi's are allowed in to drop/pick up Nice short tree lined walk to beach/shop/cafe areas through estate. Plenty of facilities, toilets/changing rooms are free to use, cafes and bars selling hot/cold snacks and drinks, ice creams etc, nice shops selling souvenirs, handicrafts, beachwear and inflatables. We hired sun beds for reasonable charge. Plenty of areas on beach to choose. Huts with tables also available if you want to escape the sun for a while. Lovely views along coast towards Store Bay, Bon Accord Lagoon, Buccoo Reef and Nylon Pool Place didn't seem too busy while we were there. Jetty for local pick up on trips to Nylon Pool and Reef and also glass bottomed boat trips available. Wind surfing, jet ski's and other water sports offered in complex. Signs displayed showing taxi charges to various locations around Tobago, so make sure you negotiate before getting in one. Really enjoyable place.

What an amazing place to visit, but not when the cruise ships are in port! Any other day very peaceful, food and drinks all available at reasonable prices. Beautiful white sand and turquoise water, it really is paradise!

This beach is beautiful, water is calm and bluer than than. It is extremely popular with locals. Sadly no rubbish bins on the beach and sadly people just leave their rubbish behind, take your litter with you.
What a great beach.  Beautiful surroundings; beautiful beach and crystal clear water.  Rent an umbrella and a chaise lounge and you are set for life!

Wow, wow, wow... What a fantastic place to visit.. First time was a Sunday. Bustling with families and people alike.. great bars and places to eat. Beautiful white Sandy Beach and a turquoise warm sea.. plenty of boat trips to visit the nylon pool and no man's land . Jet ski rides. Wind surfing. Kite surfing. Body boarding. All available to hire. We revisited on the following Wednesday. Peaceful and very quiet. All watersports still available. Less bars open but still somewhere to eat and drink. This national heritage Park is an absolute must to visit.. It truly is heaven on Earth..
Beautiful way to relax and enjoy the Caribbean sun, sand, surf in lovely turquoise waters and warm Caribbean breezes
Amazing beach, just like a postcard. Located about 20 mins from the harbour by car and with a 3 usd entry, it is very worth a visit!

We spent a few days at Pigeon Point on a recent holiday in Tobago, and the facilities are lovely. The beach is large, with clean and accessible washroom facilities and parking. The sand and water are lovely, although it can get windy. There are chairs and umbrellas for rent at 30 TT each for the day, and the equipment is nice and well maintained. There is also shade for when you want it. There is a cost to enter the park, 20TT for adults and half price for kids, which likely enables the well looked after facilities, and it shows. The only very minor complaint I would have is that the food options are limited and a bit slow; there isn‚Äôt really a large variety of ‚Äúlocal‚Äù food but rather the standard burgers and chips type fare. However, if you are more organized than we are you could bring your own! Overall, I would recommend this beach, especially for larger groups.

This beach is a Government run park. It‚Äôs very nicely kept and has your typical beach venders but they aren‚Äôt as aggressive in some places. It has all the facilities you need plus rentals for windsurfing, snorkeling etc. well worth a visit.
This is a great beach and has great sand and surf. The location is on the Caribbean side and close to the airport so it is convenient to visit.
Lots of washrooms for showering and changing. Bars on the beach for great food and refreshments. Lots of watersports available.

This place is a must go to if you‚Äôre in Tobago. Beautiful beach for all ages, covered sitting areas, food and drink stands, water sport rentals and  souvenirs. You can rent a lounge chair for the day for $5 US and it costs $40TT to enter($7 US). Most resorts offer a free shuttle to this beach. Well worth a day trip.
This is it, this is what you imagine when you back home in the cold winter. Blue Blue waters, white sandy beach....the place to hang out.
It was a realy nice beach with a good bar. The beach is nice and clean. There are a lot of tiny stones in the sea when you want to go in the sea. But besides that it is a really nice beach.

We arrived at Pigeon Point in beautiful Tobago sunshine. It is a short drive off the main road and entry is $20.00TTD per person and there is ample car parking. The beach was soft and the sand was white. The sea was light blue and glistening and clean. Lifeguards were on duty to ensure that everybody was safe. There is a bar and souvenir shops around the beach (slightly cheaper souvenirs in the shops just before you enter the gates to the beach) and there is a nice party atmosphere. The area is clean and the toilet facilities are clean and well kept. There is a choice of tours and water activities to try from if you fancy it. On a slightly sour note, as soon as you arrive at Pigeon Point, different people will walk up to you asking if you want a tour. We were promised a tour of the reef, snorkelling, bathing in Nylon Pool and a trip to No Man‚Äôs Land for $100.00TTD (¬£12.50) by a chap named Captain Hayden on the Calypso Empress. He assured us we would leave at 14:00 and return by 16:00 (we had a flight to catch.) At 14:00, he said there would be a thirty minute delay and at 14:30, he said that the price had gone up by $20.00TTD per person. He became irate when we refused to pay but said we could get on the boat anyway. The boat we were put on looked very fun-down and the driver was saying he hadn‚Äôt been given enough petrol. The tour returned at 17:00. Please avoid Captain Hayden.

If you wanna go for swing, snorkeling, rent jetskies, go on a glassbuttom boat you should go to Pigeon Point. Beautiful blue water! There is a lot of life during the weekend and a bit more quiet during the week. You have plenty of possibilities here!

Lovely beach day here at pidgeon point, 20ttd park entrance ,20ttd for sun beds ,lovely beach staff. Small  selection of gift shops and a nice selection of food outlets , Also a good water sport facility ,nice to see the wind/kite surfers. All in all great facility a must do and a great day out at a reasonable cost, we got a taxi from our hotel the tropikist and had a slow walk back.

Visited this beach twice during our weeks stay You pay 20 dollars per person to enter the beach area then 30 dollars for each sun bed Beach was lovely though and as you walk around the headland area you catch the wind from that side which cools you down. Have some lovely food from the bar area and loved every minute. You have to visit here
Small entrance fee 20TT. Immaculate,safe(lifeguards), many bars and places to eat. Toilets, changing rooms etc. (close at 4pm, beach at 5pm). Many boat trips available.

Pigeon point beach in Tobago is one of the most beautiful beaches in the world and the views and cleanliness are on point. From the sand, water, cafes, restrooms and  shower room are so damn clean. It only cost about 20TT (about $4US) for all you get. make sure and have your cameras available to take all the beautiful shots that will have you amazed. There are tour guides available if you want to go out to the coral reef. remember i told you not to forget your camera. enjoy this beach as much as I did and you will Thank me later for sure. enjoy!!!!!
Nice clean beach with toilets,showers and cafes. Small charge to get on the beach but worth a day out with jet skis and boat rides. Good value.

It costs 20TT per person (¬£2.50) to enter the Pigeon Point beach area. There are washrooms, bars and eateries along with a place to get ice cream. Beds and umbrellas are extra but the sand is soft enough to lay a towel down. Full of groups of people of all ages chill in and enjoying the day. Only about 10 mins to walk from Crown Point. You can also do the reef and Nylon Pool trips from the betty here. Worth a day.

Tobago for the win! After years of telling my trini friends they have no beaches that still holds true for Trinidad but Tobago is definitely a paradise waiting to be discovered. Pigeon Point is just so beautiful and relaxing!

I have been lucky enough to visit some very nice beaches but this is up there with the best of them. It is what everyone would picture a Caribbean beach to look like. Clean, safe you pay to get in and for sunbeds. A must visit if you are in Tobago
great location TT20 entry fee (¬£2.50)very clean and tidy, food, drink, beds, changing rooms all available great place to visit.

Pigeon point beach is a very calm beach compared to the other beaches on the island of Tobago. Their is an entry fee of $20 dollars for adults and seniors with their national id's present enter free. You can rent chairs at $30 a piece and relax whole day by the sun, sea and sand. Their are restaurants and bars on the beach and also an ice cream parlor with snacks and drinks. Everything you need for a relaxing day at the beach is at your disposal, and so worth a try. If you are interested in going out to the reef, their are also chouts present that walk around selling tickets for the reef and they tell you what time to meet the boat at the jetty to go on the tour.

The beach area and facilities are pretty nice - I don't mind paying for them.  The only annoyance was that they locked the showers around 5pm even though there were still plenty of people on the beach and swimming.

$20 TTD to get in. Very clean overall apart from stuff washed up on parts of the beach. Lifeguards on duty. Safe bathing areas. Food places, so you can get a meal and other tourist shops. There are shelters with seats and tables, toilets, showers, changing rooms, security everywhere to keep you safe. Basically all you need for a trip to the beach.
This beach had sun, sand and beautiful waters, absolutely amazing. There was food, ice cream, pop corn, drinks bar and music. Also there were jet skies rentals.
you have to pay to get in, but its peanuts and help keep the area clean, the beaches are spotless the seas are clear, the beer is cold and the food is great, what else do you need ?

Pigeon Point is a gorgeous beach with a relaxed and friendly vibe, food stalls, bars and sanitary/changing facilities. We had a great time and amazing local food and the obligatory rum punch which were all reasonably priced and delicious. Slight critique are the vendors/people hustling to sell tours and activities who are very persistent and don't take no for an answer. The water quality is great and truly inviting to swim in, overall a great experience and lovely day spent underneath the palm trees.

Amazing beach. Lots of beautiful coral. Clear water, While looking at the fish by the rocks a huge stingray swam past me.  Toilet, shower and Changing rooms along the beach. It cost $20TTD, about ¬£2.50 each to enter the beach carpark and another $30TTD to hire a lounger.  So just over ¬£6 in total for a great day at the beach.  It has good food and drink and a nice ice cream parlour. Do not miss this piece of paradise.

For my friend's birthday we spent the day here. It was so much fun. The staff were friendly and willing to help with a smile as we disrupted their busy schedules to get assistance on our scavenger hunt. Equipped with a plethora of fun activities such as: stand up paddling, wind surfing, kayaking or just simply being in the water, being bored is near to impossible.

Pigeon Point is beautiful and I hope to return on a sunny day.  We happened to visit on a rainy day, and still had lots of fun.  The water is warm and clear and perfect for younger kids to experience snorkeling near the shore.  The only reason I give it a 4 is because this was the only time on our Tobago visit when I felt like a tourist; there were touristy shops selling trinkets and much of the food was geared to tourists, although we did manage to find bake and shark and goat curry!  You also have to pay to enter the park....and can probably have just as lovely a beach experience for free at Store Bay.  I will say the visit was totally worth it to see the kids have fun in the soft sand and in the water.  Also, you must visit Planet Ceramics, and absolutely beautiful shop full of handmade ceramics!  I wish I had more room in my suitecase to take back dozens of items from Planet Ceramics!!!

Pigeon Point is beautiful, fringed with palm and almond trees and shallow waters for swimming. There are a few little reefs for snorkeling just off shore with loads of pretty fish. Stand still and you'll be lucky to get a few black fin jacks coming close (they won't hurt you they're just inquisitive). There are toilets, showers and changing rooms along with a cafe serving tasty local food and a bar with a larger range of foods (the curry with shredded roti is really good). Yes, you will get brokers trying to book you on the snorkeling /nylon pool /no man's land tour but a firm no and they'll move on if you are not interested. We did do the tour on a quiet boat and the snorkeling is fantastic we saw lovely brain coral, giant pufferfish and Angelfish amongst many others! Nylon pool was spoiled by the noisy Frankie tours boat mooring up and ruining the tranquillity. They should coordinate so the quieter boats go at a different time to the "party" boats.
The most relaxing experience. The beach is clean and the water is clear. The workers are kind. Will surely return.

This clean beach has beautiful clear blue water, trees and an outstanding infrastructure: bar, restaurant, showers, toilets, life guard, chairs and umbrellas (paid). There is lots to see and find on the shore. The only drawback are the recently sprouted algae approximately 10 m from shore when you wade in. But swimming - even in the rain - is a bliss. Snorkeling is not worth while here, rather take a boat tour to the corals.
Pigeon Point beach is a must do when on Tobago.  I enjoyed watching my grandson Jetski and swim here.  It is worth the small price of admission.

Th i s beautiful, really stunning beach is very safe for swimming and has a life guard presence. Good facilities including clean eating places , bars, clean toilets and plenty of shade,which is very important in the hot sun!!
Beautiful beach, a lot of friendly people and good places to eat. Loads of chances to do boat trips around the island. However can sometimes feel pestered by it.

Nice safe clean beach, with lifeguards and a few bars and restaurants and excellent clean loos. Plenty of shade but sun beds and umbrellas to hire.  People do try to sell you boat trips etc but they‚Äôre polite and not pushy.
Just relaxing by the Caribbean sea . A few shops and Restaurants and Bars . Good food , very friendly people . ITS A MUST to visit .
Beautiful beaches, facilities to seat, eat or just trees to be in the shade. Suitable for families with young children. Departure of boats for nylon pool and other spots. A must see in Tobago.

Went three times during a weeks stay on the island. 20tt to get in to the resort and 20tt for sun beds. Quieter during the week - with all the cabanas booked at the weekend. Sugar lips glass bottom boat by far the best. Smaller without blaring music and not overcrowded the beach is stunning with safe area for swimming. Humming birds everywhere. Quieter during the morning. Well worth a visit. Taxis can be hard to find at the weekend, but random local gave me a lift back to hotel for a few quid!

We wanted to snorkel on the reef, but the way to get out there is by going on the glass bottom boats.  Unfortunately these have a fixed routine for visits that involve opportunities for gliding over the reef and looking through the glass bottom of the boat, snorkeling (but not freely - you have to stay close to the boat, understandable but frustrating), standing around in shallow water at the Nylon Pool and visiting a sandbar for some reason.  I guess we should have tried to get a dedicated dive shop to take us out, as our boat was largely occupied by visitors who could not swim and were more interested in the free beer and rum punch.  A lively outing but not really what we wanted, especially as the short time we had snorkeling showed the reef has good potential if you only had more time and freedom. The beach itself was very nice - good facilities and not at all crowded, but we were very much visiting "out of season".

I'm full Trinidad so this was new to me because i never left Trinidad overseas to Tobago. as we got on the boat to go to Pigeon Point Beach i was surprised on how good it looks when there was a lot of people there. the tour said the the sand is also use of soap. it a good location  to do some sun bathing with the Caribbean wind. it also a good spot to get a Caribbean view as well to sea the wildlife. the food was 10/10 with that Caribbean blend of spices, and it good security for a beach. the family had a blast of fun time and good pictures to show to their friends

Pigeon point is a lovely spot for soaking up the sun. There is a entrance fee for you and vechile, but worth the money as place is very well looked maintained......visited the place 4 yrs earlier and the only difference there is definitely beach erosion right on the point itself. Think this could become a issue for the bar right on the sand.....other than this it still is a lovely place to relax

We spent the day at Pigeon Point Beach. You pay 20TT per adult but the facilities are clean and security very visible. People will try to sell you the Nylon Pool your but just say no. The average tour is about 100TT. We didn‚Äôt go on the tour. People were friendly they have a bar, ice cream shop, etc. We enjoyed our beach day!

Pigeon Point is a stunning beach. The pale sand and the palm trees. The warm sea water. There are also great bars and restaurants and the locals who work there are all really friendly and welcoming. It does cost to visit, but it isn't expensive and it's worth it for the upkeep as the beach is really clean. Sunbeds also cost but ,again, they aren't much and they keep you away from any sand flies. There are small huts dotted along the beach, for those who want a seat out of the sun, and trees also offer some shade. The amenities  are clean and well kept. It was our favourite beach to visit while we were in Tobago
It really is worth paying to visit this gorgeous beach, with its powdery sand and warm blue water.........as with everywhere on the island you feel safe here and that is a massive plus.

Beautiful beach, boat tour to Nylon Pool was fun and exciting, Food at the restaurant was delicious. Not much space once it gets crowded. Not liking the fact that we were Americans and were charge high fees for the Glass Bottom Boat Tour, when citizens of Trinidad, paid half the price.

We went to pigeon point and the staff that do the boat tours are so rude! We bought out tickets for a glass bottom boat tour before and when it was time to meet on this ‚Äòfamous‚Äô pier with thatched roof these local guys said to my wife are you going on the boat trip? She said yes and one other guy said‚Äù give me your ticket‚Äù we didn‚Äôt trust them as they all look so dodgy over there with hostile manners, incidentally they rely on tourists but speak to you like a piece of s..t!,so it turns out one of these ‚Äòmen‚Äô?! Was the boat owner ‚Äòswanky tours‚Äô.. the glass bottom boat had water leaking on the glass swashing about so you couldn‚Äôt see anything, there was no toilet on board yet they said before we paid there was , and hardly any fish to see, I was with my 6 year old and they were playing cardi b music with swearing! NOT a family tour! 2.5 hours later I could not wait to get off! The bar they have there had a local behind the bar who had zero people skills and no manners, you got the impression you were bothering him to spend money in there, I‚Äôm told by a man from Trinidad that this was normal as they have no training! Sorry not acceptable! The beach however is amazing, there are picnic tables as well beer is relatively cheap, but food is basic, chips burgers, chicken, takes forever for food to arrive and then another idiot missed some of our order! If you like customer service, goto Barbados and give Tobago a wide berth!

There is a $20.00 TT entrance fee per adult children under 12 pay $10.00. There is available parking and lots of water sports starting from about $50.00 TT. I love that the showers and changing rooms are free. Beach chairs are available at $30.00 TT the umbrellas are priced separate. It's not the ideal place for snorkelling your not going to see much.

A must visit on Tobago in Heritage Park. Day passes needed (20TT per day) to visit. Great facilities with excellent clean toilets and showers. Several food places serving a wide range of food and drink. Quieter in the week but gets busier in the evenings and at weekends. Swimming area fairly limited because of the jet-skis and tour boats but never feels too crowded in the quiet seasons. Plenty of parking. Excellent water sports centre.

Clear sand and water,its totally worth it to take a week entrance. Ive met a tour guide hes name is Keino,he work for Keino twin isle tours,rented a jet ski ride and took two tours from him,highly recommend to find him if youre in Tobago.

If relaxing with young children this place is ideal for a visit. 20tt$ (3us$) per adult entrance fee is well worth it.  Each conveniences and a well stocked bar is available. Taxis are available to and from. About 30 minutes leisurely walk to a store Bay. The. Real water here provides a shallow lagoon ideal for young kids.
Lovely beach. great facilities,  I would get there early before 10am to claim a hut.  Only potential down side to some would be if the bar at the end has a music day.  We prefer Store Bay

Pigeon point is a beautiful beach but a lot of coral on the sand and into the water that hurt your feet. You must walk through the coral to get to the soft sand about 10 feet. Beach also has seaweed in the water and on shore in certain places. The bar is nice and fun but the food vendors are not good. You must pay $20TT to get in and $30TT for a lounger, which they track by giving you a bracelet. We could not find anyone to help us get chairs so we got it ourselves. But they later hunt you down for their money.

We had a great beach day here the beach attendant put the beds just where we wanted them the beach was spotless, the turquoise sea, great ice cream, and spotless amenities. Apparently rays swimming around the jetty.
Once in Tobago you must visit Pigeon Point.  The facility is pristine and picturesque.  You can relax on the white sand or enjoy a water sport.
This is a really lovely Beach and I'm definitely looking forward to see the beach again the bar is pretty well run by Akeem
Here is so beautiful and all you could wish for is on a beach. Nice changing room and toilets. Several places where you can pick up snacks and drinks

Beautiful beach ! Small entrance  fee to a soft sandy beach, warm calm ocean , lifeguards and beach restaurant! Brought a cooler with some drinks and fold up beach chairs but there were loungers available for rent and places to buy a drink and food. There were Very clean washrooms ,well maintained gardens and boats available to get out to see the reef and nylon pool..definitely recommended !!!!! We had a great lunch at the beach bar.. Bake and shark,and curry crab and dumplings, and fish in a bun ... Everyone was raving about their meals ... Generous rum punches and icy cold beer capped off the day!
Such a lovely tranquil place and totally un spoilt , go swim in the waterfall it was just lovely so refreshing on a hot day and feels so nice on your skin and hair
Always plenty of shade from the trees, lovely safe swimming, clean white sand. Eateries at reasonable prices. Homemade ice cream...plenty of drinks. Sun loungers available. Toilets/showers

Paradise, like beauty, is in the eyes of the beholder. Each morning, afternoon, and evening that I had the opportunity to be in the warm embrace of pigeon point, I thoroughly enjoyed every moment of its healing tranquility, even with the vast amount of cruise ship visitors. We rented chairs at a reasonable cost from friendly attendants, arranged to be set up in the shade of a lush coconut trees on the 'quiet' side of the happy crowds, near by to 'Radical Sports', where we were impressed by the agility of the kite and wind surfers. Clean soft sand beaches, turqoise island water, and plenty of practical amenities available. Paradise! Enjoy it!

What a stunning beach! The sand is white and the sea is turquoise. A little bit of paradise to soak up some Caribbean sun. When we visited, the beach was not too busy and we found the ideal spot for us. The sun beds were comfortable and clean. The toilet facilities were very clean, which makes a nice change compared to lots of other places. I' will admit to not really being a beach lover, but will make an exception for this little bit of paradise. Stunning.

This place has been upgraded again and is very pretty.  The jetty is kind of part of the Caribbean dream.  The water is clear and turquoise.  There are lots of activities available including windsurfing, glass bottom boats to the reef and the Nylon Pool.  Lots of parking space and little shops and some eateries.  There is a small fee to get it and, if you're up to it, I'd suggest walking as the way down is really beautiful

This beach is gorgeous! White sands, turquoise water. There were some areas to snorkel around but the water is very very shallow. We went around 9:30 am and it was already very busy. You have to pay to rent chairs and umbrellas at all the beaches which wasn't an issue as there were many, but finding a place to put chairs was difficult without being on top of another person. We went jet skiing here which was very fun, but it was around wind surfers which you had to be cautious. They were offered at Store Bay as well which probably would have been more fun. People were very friendly. We had some crab and dumplings at the little restaurant. Not my favorite- little bits of shells in the meat. They had a fresh bqq after we order which would have been more desirable. It cost money to get into the beach- I think around 10 US $. It was very beautiful just not my favorite due to the amount of people there.

Nice beach with all amenities. Charged $30TT per person to get in & were given a wristband (2 chairs & umbrella for the day $90TT). Popular place, kinda crowded but nothing too special. Was clean, safe & had everything you'd want or expect. There are better beaches around but it was nice & had everything.

The beach is great for young children, soft sand, places to eat on the beach, homemade ice cream available, shops for any beach wear/accessories you may have forgotten to bring... You pay $20TT per adult and $10 for kids 5 to 12 years old, under 5 years -free. The actual food, ice cream, drinks and physical beach are all super! The beach staff act as if you are bothering them, if you buy ice cream, the attendant acts bothered to get off her phone to prepare it, the grilled food people act bothered to prepare your order and worst of the all is the lounge chair police. So there is a rule governing the use of loung chairs, so be aware. First you pay someone for a lounge chair, $30TT, the person you pay is not the same person who distributes the lounge chair. The lounge chair staff are always moving around so you have to look for them. You will receive a wristband for the chair, if you are with a group of people, two persons cannot sit on a loung chair, only one adult at a time , the adult with the wrist band. So My husband and I had two chairs, my 3 year old is eating on one and my husband and I are sitting facing opposite directions on the other one, this was pointed out as a violation of the loung chair policy. Another day, we were there, my toddler fell asleep in my arms, I asked my husband to get a chair so our son can sleep on it. It took him 30 mins to find the staff operating the lounge chair. We really did not want to participate in the lounge chair politics, but to have someplace comfortable for my son to sleep, we decided to go through the stress. When my husband couldn‚Äôt wait any more cause my arm was so tired, he took the chair then lounge chair police showed up. Then there was the table/bench usage. So my party consisted of 8 persons, two cars, we occupied two tables /4 benches. We were told by the staff we could only occupy one table even though we were buying lunch and had 8 persons with us. So many more examples, but you get the picture. The employees there, not sure if they are trained adequately to deal with tourists. They act as if you are bothering them and it seems they dont want you there. They act brothered and angry. If you can ignore the service, this place is great

My family of four spent the better part of our Tobago trip at Pigeon Point. We came for the watersports and stayed for the friendly people, clean facilities and gorgeous beach. It's about $3 USD per day, per person. Do the math to see if the $100 TTD for a week is a better deal. I'm already missing the local ice cream and the curry. Cute shops, nice people, great beach.

Arriving in Tobago on a cruise ship we joined four other passengers and hired a mini bus to take us to Pigeon Point for $10 each. On arrival our driver pointed out the amenities such as toilets, restaurant, bar, etc., and advised us that if we required a sunbed we hire one immediately as they soon disappeared. At another $10 each they were a bit pricey, but within half an hour there  were no more available. The weather was glorious, as was the beach and ocean, with food and drink available at reasonable prices with reggae music in the air. Our driver stayed, along with several other drivers, giving us peace of mind that we would return to our cruise ship on time and we thoroughly enjoyed our day at the beach

Beautiful beach with all the facilities you need, although when we drove here we didn‚Äôt have a clue what to expect and had to ask at the desk! Should have revised!! Teens went jet skiing which they really enjoyed although an hour is a bit too long. Meanwhile hubby had eucalyptus rubbed over his burnt spots by dr feelgood (pedlar) who was lovely and not pushy at all, so funny! Spent the afternoon here and ate at the bar which was cheap and delicious, fine fir what we needed. Swimming g and shade good.  A must for any visitor. Will be back again.

Stunning peace of nature.  Well maintained. Awesome is one word to describe this area.  Clear blue and aqua seas, huts on the beach.  You can paddle board, catch a boat tour, jet ski or enjoy the scenery. Lovely. $20 per person all day.

Pideon point used to be very beautiful but it is now a nasty tourist visit. The cruise ships dump thousands of passengers there so with about two toilet you can imagine where people go for a P. The resut is the water is totally polluted Not worth going to.

It was the week before Easter when we went so not as busy as some other reviewers have experienced. This is stunningly beautiful part of Tobago and you have to pay a small admittance fee which goes towards the upkeep, lots of places to eat and drink, lovely beach and lovely seas.

You have to pay ¬£2 per person to go onto this beach. It is a coral beach so you really need shoes. The water can be very choppy. Avoid like the plague when the cruise ships are in. Everyone getting drunk and very noisy. The steel band is pleasant and all water sports are available.

So you get minibus or taxi from the port about 20 minutes from cruise port. Be aware the road can be very busy so leave plenty of time to return. You pay a few dollars to get in and then pay for loungers. We got there about 11am and there were no loungers left so get there early. There are bars and stalls and plenty of shade. Aside from the crowds this is a truly beautiful white sandy beach set in a National Park so the backdrop from the beach is lush vegetation. There are water sports available and you can get in the water quite easily, it was quite windy when we went but the sea was relatively calm. The pier makes for some fab photo opportunities and the beach is pretty long with some rocky outcrops.

Beautiful sands, great facilities plus a few shops/stalls selling beach bits & gifts. Planet ceramics being one of them & sells beautiful hand made ceramics. Second visit we went on the glass bottom boat. What a treat, snorkelling on the reef & feeling 10 years younger after swimming at the Nylon Pool.
2 visits in 1 week. Lovely. Very clean. Great toilets and very good security. Good value for money. Can't wait to return

Pigeon point beach is gorgeous. There is a small fee, 3or 4 usd entrance fee but well worth it. There are food and merchant vendors. Also, very new restroom facilities. Many water sports to watch enjoying the wind and surf. Enjoy the tranquility of this natural unspoiled beautiful beach.

Pigeon point is a privately run beach on a small penninsula. Yes you have the picture almost everybody knows of, the thatched hut at the end of the wooden pier that is a good camera shot I must admit. This beach was so so crowded it felt uncomfortable, getting in the water you had to avoid the pebbles and the steep incline otherwise it took you by surprise. The changing facilities were not very clean and the beach showers did not work, not exactly a blue flag beach.I certainly would not buy food from any of the restaurants I saw a door open to one and it was not very clean. Yes you have the blue Caribbean Sea but that's about it.

This beach is one of the most peaceful beaches I have ever been too. It doesn't the typical beach energy, it feels more like a secret weekend getaway. I never liked it when I was younger because I thought it was boring, but now I do like it.

20TT fee is worth it ! Beach is clean , and has many bathrooms ( the cleanliest beach bathroom I‚Äôve ever seen). There are several bars and food stands. I recommend not going when the cruise ships are in, the beach was very crowded.
good sheltered place to swim and get a whole lot of sun. bottom was sandy and a easy walk out from the beach. great blue color to the water.

We visited several beaches in our week and found Pigeon Point to be the best beach. Good location, happening bar, chairs and umbrella available. We would of returned on our last day however in rained all day. Best choice!

This is a fabulous beach to visit suitable for all the family particularly a safe roped off area for adults and kids to swim safely away from all the water traffic. There is a small charge to get in which is worth every penny as it keeps all the hawkers out so nobody bothers you. The gardens are beautiful and kept up immaculately clean. The beach toilets are the cleanest l have ever seen and are kept clean and restocked all day. There are sun beds for hire which cost about ¬£1 a day and they will put them where you want. There is plenty of shade given by the trees so umbrellas are not needed. The sea temperature when l was there was so warm you weren't really sure you were in the water. Not much to see in the water as the reef here has been destroyed. Very sad but there are lots of people selling trips out to the reef to go snorkeling which are well worth it. Not for the faint hearted as the currents are very strong and you have to hold a rope all the time but great fun. There are 2 bars and a great wind surfing centre on the beach so food and drink is available all day. Would recommend this beach to everyone it is gorgeous.

Think the Tobago version of Blackpool. A popular beach and the most photographed. Great if you want bars, toilets and sports close to hand but if you want typical Tobago then go to an unspoiled beach elsewhere.

This beach is special! we have enjoyed it in the typical Caribbean sunshine and 30 degrees and still enjoyed it in a tropical storm.  You know you are in the right place when there are lots of locals enjoying themselves!  Perfect beach, good facilities for showering/changing. Plenty of parking (if you have hired a car!).  Food and drinks readily available.  But, above all! a perfect beach to swim!

We spent a day here and there are so many pluses and minuses. It is the only beach we had to pay to visit and then pay again for a bed. There are other beaches on Tobago which are as good (but smaller). There are many that are less windy. What Pigeon Point provides is convenience. Easy parking, lots of room, showers, toilets. There is also a huge amount of wildlife to enjoy. Why oh why do they allow a ‚Äòfast food ‚Äò restaurant that doesn‚Äôt thaw the frozen fish until the order is taken. An hour wait for mediocre fish and chips is very disappointing. We only had 14 days on Tobago and were so looking forward to visiting Pigeon Point. If we return to the island we won‚Äôt come back here

Pigeon Point is one of the "must visit" places in Tobago and when you see it you will understand why. The beach is everything you want it to be, clear white sand and amazing blue sea. You have to pay to get in, $20TTD per person and then on top of this you have to pay to hire loungers and umbrellas which is like anywhere else. And from there you can do water sports, glass bottom boat tours or just sit in the sun and drink rum. There is a variety of places to eat and many places to get a drink! The only "negative" thing I will say about Pigeon Point is that if you are going to Tobago in high season or when there is a cruise ship in port, you must get there early or you risk not getting a lounger, umbrella or even a decent spot to put your towel!! To give you an idea, when i arrived on a non-ship day at 10am, there were 4 loungers in use on the entire stretch of beach..... when i arrived at 11am on a "ship day" there wasn't a single lounger or umbrella available!

I had the good fortune to visit Pigeon Point some 60 years ago when it was a fairly little visited but wonderful area of beach. The area is now a National Heritage park, well organised and beautifully maintained. The beach and bathing are as wonderful as ever and everything is efficient from paying for a sun bed which is then put exactly where you want it to the Restrooms, bars and eating spots. Yes it can become crowded but well worth a visit or two or ..........the approach through parkland of palms is lovely.
Lovely place to spend the day.   Spotless facilities.  Sun bed hire.  Bars.  Stalls.  Glass bottom boats.  When you go you‚Äôll want to go back.

We visited Pigeon Point during our stay in Tobago. The grounds are amazing and very well kept. It‚Äôs cost $20TTD per person to enter the grounds for the day. The beach was packed! It was super busy. The water was great however. My favorite part was the nutmeg ice cream! It was everything! Not sure if I would visit the beach again during the high season because it‚Äôs so crowded. Would do it again during another time. It‚Äôs a great place for a wedding!

A beautiful beach, well maintained with excellent facilities. There are beach bars and shops but they don't spoil the beauty of the pristine sands.  Perfect for swimming with lifeguards present.  There iis a small entrance charge to the beach aeea but well worth it. Recommended.

Well worth a visit- beautiful beaches and facilities such as toilets are well maintained and clean. Choices for food which are reasonably priced. Costs 20TT dollars per person to enter but sun beds etc are well priced. Lots of people offering boat trips but all good humoured and not too intrusive.

We took the 11:00 AM Shuttle at the Magdalena resort in route to Pigeon Point upon arriving at Pigeon Point Beach a fee of $20.00 TT per person to enter Pigeon Point once inside there are lots of activities, Glass bottom boat, Jet sky or take a relaxing swim, there are lots of activities, bar , souvenirs shop. I highly recommend going to Pigeon Point Beach.

We loved Pigeon Point and having done our research made sure we visited when there were no cruise boats in. It was a lovely clean beach well-maintained with some beds and umbrellas for hire along with changing areas and toilets. We found it was safe for swimming as the sand didn't slope away too steeply. There  was a rope marking of the area for swimming from the occasional jet ski and boats. Really beautiful.

This beach is an island paradise. We visited the week before Trinidad Carnival and for the most part couldn‚Äôt believe how reasonably quiet it was for such a wonderful location. However, on our last day there a Cruise ship docked leashing thousands of patrons onto the beach. It was horrendous. If you are unfortunate enough to catch this, the only saving grace is that they leave around 2.30pm.
A turtle nesting area which also has sandy beaches for swimming / windsurfing etc. plus toilets and a bar etc. You can just call in for a quick visit or spend day there.
I really enjoyed this beach and the park is beautiful as well. It‚Äôs nice and quiet and there‚Äôs not an over abundance of people

Pigeon Point beach is a very beautiful beach with white sand and amasing blue water. Sunbeds are available for rent. There is a bar, a restaurant and changing room. We took a taxi from the cruise terminal to the beach, which was 50 US $ for 4 adults round trip. Very good price considering that an excursion to this beach organised by the excursion office on the ship was about 100 US $ for 2 adults. So, for those of you who are on a cruise and want to visit this beach, go on a private tour, it's way cheaper.

Pigeon point was one of the most beautiful places I have ever been to on this earth but that was 25 years ago when it was a beautiful unspoilt beach, a shack and the rickety pier. Now it is totally commercialised with rickety old boats, bailing out water mooring up to take passenegers to Bucco Reef and the Nylon Pool. Sunbeds are packed like sardines on the stretch of beach and their are bars, food outlets and souvenier shops crammed into the beach front. There are touts everywhere trying to get your business for a boat ride ot a taxi. Coach parties and cruise ship passengers which are shipped in for the day, and everything is in US dollars, You can pay for a beer in TT dollars, if you can get served as there are two people behind the main bar and the bar is 4 deep. The view in your picture is the Pigeon Point I remenber and is not a representation of how it actually is now. So disappointed.
The sea is alovely colour and shallow lovely white sand beach with bars sunbeds to hire showers and changing rooms fantastic
Stunning beach especially when quiet e.g. on Monday mornings.  Paradise on a very beautiful beach.  Can get too busy with cruise ships are in island.

Recently visited Tobago and Pigeon Point Beach  . This beach is  beautiful ,nice sand and amazing water.  It's very clean, has a restaurant ,a bar and change rooms .If you stay late you can also enjoy the beautiful sunset. Chairs are available for rent. There is an entrance fee but definitely worth it.

Nice stretch of beach that offers windsurfing, paddle boarding and more.  You pay to get in and also for chairs but it‚Äôs worth it.  Cute little shops and food is available at places right on the beach.  Not all of them are open everyday but that seems to be everywhere on the island.  Open as they feel like it!

My husband and I went here for a few hours. There is an entrance fee and you are given a wrist band to wear. There is water sports, food concessions, chair rentals, gazebos and souvenir shops. There is also a washroom.  You could easily spend the whole day there.

This beach is definitely worth a visit.  Beautiful sand and water.  Bathrooms are available. And so is beer and food.  A nice restaurant on the north end.  Windward side is also on the north side of the park.  Huge kite riders and wind surfers are plentiful.  Don‚Äôt miss this beach. You will definitely enjoy your time there.
Must visit while in Tobago. Absolutely stunning 20TT to get into the beach but well worth it Take the coral reef tour while there.

We spent the day at Pigeon Point and a great day was had by all. We rented chairs and umbrellas and hung out close to Renmars restaurant/bar. We had food and drinks from there. The day was beautiful, the water was lovely and the bathrooms are clean. What more can u ask for? Water shoes. I did find some glass in the sand by the shore. Not much but a few big pieces that were probably from a broken bottle and there were a some size-able rocks that we had to step on to go in deeper. Not a big deal. No one was hurt and the day was amazing.
This was a lovely park to walk through ending on  a lovely beach. Nice spot to have a drink and enjoy the sunset. There appears to be a lot of activity on this beach for those who love water sports.

A really beautiful place to visit ... For a small fee you can stay from 9am till 5pm. Sun beds also need to be paid for ($5)... there are a few bars and eating holes .. water sports, glass bottom boats but best of all the white sand and beautiful sea ... A real gem, we will be returning ü§ó

Annually in January I travel abroad with my two college aged daughters and best friend.  This year we chose to spend our holiday in T&T, specifically Crown Point, Tobago. We accessed Pigeon Point beach through Pigeon Point Heritage Park.  The entrance fee was $TT 20 per adult.  There are lounge chairs for rent---$TT 18 per chair.  Umbrellas are available too but there is also a significant amount a shade on the beach and we did not need an umbrella.  Bring your own sun screen and towels. The beach was spectacular.  It was very clean and the water was clear---no seaweed or other debris.  There is a bar, ice cream shop, snack shop, restaurant, and even a vendor that grills lobster and fish located near the jetty.  Amenities also include a very nice bathroom with showers. The atmosphere was family friendly and all amenities were well maintained.  Go early and make it a day, the park and beach close at 5:00 pm. I'd like to also recommend Terry's Tours & Rentals for ALL of your touring, excursion, lodging, meals and transportation needs.  Mr. Terry provided superior customer service and went above and beyond to insure that our safety, security, and comfort needs were met.   He's a credible and reliable resource for all things Tobago (Nylon Boat Tours, Fishing Excursions, Water Sport Rentals, Historical Tours, Restaurants, Bars and more) and can provide a wealth of information for anyone new to the island or returning visitors. Mr. Terry is trustworthy and delivers a professional, quality service that will exceed your expectations.  Contact him for all your tourism needs at Pigeon Point Beach and more...tell him Kola sent you his way 1868-302-6964.

This Beach is located 10 min from the airport and one of the popular beaches in Tobago. The water is calm and shallow which makes it great for family outings. Hut and chair rentals are available and sufficient bathrooms are on site. There is an entrance fee to access this beach via car. Approaching tour operators can be a nuisance sometimes.
First came here 37 years ago. It has changed a lot and is much busier now. However it is still beautiful. Always come back here when we are on Tobago.

Very nice beach. U pay entry, about 20TTD but u'll get a nice, clean beach with nice people. Food and drinks available and also toura and jetski! Definitely worth to visit! A lot of activities to do...

Sadly ruined in recent years by it becoming a money spinner.  Clot offers bars, music, food and a very crowded small expanse of beach with sun beds at a cost. It used to be so peaceful.... how times change eh

This is a beautiful beach with white sand and turquoise waters.  You have to pay to get in, then pay for a sunlounger and umbrella.  You are then hustled by men trying to sell tickets for glass bottomed boat trips almost continually.  It is very annoying.
Definitely worth a visit, views are perfect bright blue sea, white sand & the iconic thatched roof jetty we have some lovely picsüòç

Taxi from cruise ship $10 each return. $3.50 for access to beach and $5 for a sun lounger. Lovely spot with palm trees and nice sand. Not good for snorkelling but for $20 you can get a glass bottomed boat to a reef. Toilet facilities available and food and drink is very reasonable.

A privately-held beach that charges admission, but reasonable.  There are also lounges for rent.  A nice clean facility, sufficient parking, and a gentle lapping type beach, very good for small children.  There are jet skis, bananna-raft tows, and glass bottom boats that journey to the nearby nylon pool to allow viewing of the dead reef.  There is a little low-grade hassling by the tour and rental promoters, but nothing invasive or aggressive.  All in all, a nice little haven for young families, and close to the airport if it's departure day.

Very nice facilities. Loved the jet skis.  Water was nice and calm, however there was a jelly fish incident at the beach today.  Would love to see where there are all sorts of food and local cuisine available at the beach.

column7: New Forest National Park Hampshire, UK
column11: 20tt dollar entrance fee. A nicely kept large garden area with some seating, plenty of water sports available but irritating salesmen ready to pester for a sale, personally i like to decide in my own time what i want to do. Various glass bottom boats for a reef trip and others for snorkelling, jet ski's, wind surfing etc. A couple of bar/restaurants  which were clean and not to expensive. The beaches had public changing rooms and toilets which were clean but it was a quiet day, the only let down was the beach itself which was covered in various forms of broken shell, coral, and vegetative rubbish.

I'm not sure if it is the geographical location but Pigeon Point is definitely the safest beach on the island for children! The waters are crystal clear and the most gorgeous shade of blue you could ever imagine. There are lifeguards on duty and beach loungers available for rent. Tables and booths to hang out or store your belongings. There are on site restaurants where you can purchase food or bring your stuff and have a picnic. Bars to have a cold brew and if you are there visit Basso's restaurant and bar for delicious local cuisine and wonderful mixed drinks. A wedding at this site would be the most perfect day......consider it.

Drive past all of the hawkers at the entrance and you are then into a haven of tranquillity after the hubbub of the town behind you. We had a great lunch of barracuda at the restaurant before setting out to the reef and the Nylon Pool in one of the flat-bottomed boats. We were lucky enough to see a turtle swimming beneath the boat. We did not see that much when snorkelling, which was a bit of a disappointment and standing in the Nylon Pool, a kilometre offshore, in the pouring rain, was a weird experience.
Excellent beach and adequate and good facilities, clean washrooms, as again every where i went on the island i found the people to be very nice and welcoming

Visited the place 4yrs ago and was shocked to see so much had been eroded away with the obvious bad weather the island must of had. This problem must be addressed as the beach bar at the end of the point won‚Äôt be there in a Year‚Äôs time

Very clean beach.  They do charge a small fee to enter but well worth it.  We visited two weeks ago.  They also rent chairs, ten US dollars for two chairs.   The water is calm.  We paid fifty US dollars for our family of four to take a two hours boat ride which included snorkeling and visiting the nylon pool , well worth the money.  The beach is absolutely beautiful.  There is also food available and small shops.

Beast beach in T&T. The white sand and blue green water cannot be beat. Service in main restaurant is very slow. Lots of amenities and water sports available. Cost $20 TTD to go in but worth it still.

This is the kind of beach which comes to mind when you think of the Caribbean, beautiful clean sand and warm clear water fantastic. Also try the music bar on the beach great food and lovely rum punch. The entry fee of 20TT dollars  is just under ¬£2.50 each.

I LOVE Pigeon Point. I love seeing on the northern side that faces Nylon Pool. The wind allows for paragliders to take full advantage of it, and the light blue sea into the cove of No Man's Land and Buccoo is more beautiful that words can describe.

Good washrooms, easy to get something to eat. Sufficient seating and clean beach. Only one downfall ..... smokers were allowed to smoke right outside the eating area, which is against the law in T&T. We have young kids nearby, second hand smoke is not acceptable.
Gorgeous beach.   We went late afternoon and ended up sitting at the bar  drinking and chatting to a couple of locals.   I did however manage to have a dip in the sea.   What more can you say.

Must See when visiting Tobago.. The view is breathtaking.. The Beach Awesome... Since I have last been here there have been a few upgrades with is nice to see. The Bathrooms were clean and the Food keeps you wanting more. Staff on the beach were very friendly which completes your stay...

A nature preserve, 20TT to enter ($2.50US). Has restaurants and board rentals and lessons (Radical Sports Tobago).  Nice sandy beaches with protected swimming area, with lifeguards. Clean well kept bathrooms with fresh water showers. Vendors selling snorkellling tours, glass bottom boats, jet skis, but they are respectful, don't hassle you once you say no thanks. Wind set up is excellent ... big bay for flat water, reefs offshore for waves.  RST will do boat rescues for a fee if you have troubles.

Wish the weather our first week was not mostly rain or we would have visited Pigeon Point then and would certainly have revisited. Had a great day on the beach, lovely sandy area, water beautiful,  Everywhere including washrooms kept nice and clean and tidy.  Showers outside washrooms to wash off the salt and sand.  A variety of food and drinks available at reasonable prices,  Sunbeds and Umbrellas available at reasonable prices too.  Lots of free seating at Bench/tables, some under cover.  Well worth the TTD20 per head entry to keep the area in great condition.

We spent an hour there, ate very badly at a cafe/bar with stunningly rude staff. Lots of people telling you what not to do. It's a government- run "beach facility", a gated community, really. Honestly, rent a car or take a taxi to one of the much more beautiful places in the rainforest up the Caribbean coast - Englishman's Bay or Castara. Much lovelier, much more authentic, and perfectly safe.
Beautiful place to spend the day on the beach .lots of restroom ,and a few bars on the beach . There a few small gift shops there too.

We visited here on 2 occasions, one time it was really quiet, not many people around - that was lovely! A real paradise! There are quite a few guys trying to sell boat trips, they are mostly friendly and fun and like to have a bit of banter. You have to pay 20TT to gain access this covers the services on the beach, toilets are clean and work, plenty of showers, beautiful clean beach and sea, nice tourist shops, couple of bars, take away food/drink. The second time was a Tobago holiday day so the beach was packed!! A very different feel, its still lovley but I preferred the calm chilled paradise feel! If you visit Tobago you really must visit as it really is stunning!!

Pigeon Point is a little bit more mainstream for our liking but the snorkelling was some of the best we have ever experienced.  We were up near the beach bar so drinks and snacks were easy to get when needed.  We also hired a couple of jet skis and went to No Mans Land, which is just across the bay.  Great way to get away from people for your own private beach. I even saw a manta ray when I was sitting in the shallow water at No Mans Land, it just glided past me.

The water here is usually clear and calm enough for your children to bathe unsupervised. The warmth of the sun is felt while bathing. There are a few places right on the beach front where you can purchase food and drinks so no need for a picnic basket.

We walked straight to the beach first thing in the morning from the airport (1.5 miles). It cost 20 TTD each and we had some of the most pristine beaches all to ourselves for most of the morning. The sand is beautiful and fine, shaded just the right amount by palm trees. The water is warm and shallow with buoys and rope to keep everyone safe from boats, etc further off the beach. The only drawback was in the afternoon when dozen of school-aged children/teenagers arrived. They had clearly not paid and were very noisy detracting from the calm and slightly ruining the end of the day.
We only walked around the beaches and gardens.  But the sea looked wonderful and if we had not been limited for time we could have spent hours here.

Beautiful beach, but a little over commercialized for the tourists. Safe spot for swimming with a few bars, restaurants and souvenir shops. There also an admission charge for entry to the Pigeon point headland. To be honest, Tobago has nicer spots that you can visit for free if you're prepared to head off the beaten track.

Pigeon point and Tobago as a whole is a hidden gem to visit.  It‚Äôs raw/ rustic and un-commercialized ways set it apart from everywhere else in the Caribbean I‚Äôve personally visited. Pigeon point is a great private beach.  Cost is 20tt pp to enter. You get a wristband. Our hotel (the Magdalena Grand) offered a free shuttle to the beach two times per day which was handy. Beach is well maintained. No Seagrass issues. Water is calm and warm. Caribbean Sea side There are jet skis available for rent. We paid $480tt for 1 hour through Justin / Terry.  $240 tt for half an hour.  Was a great experience !! If your thinking of doing Nylon Pool / No Mans land while you are there I would recommend going this route vs the glass bottom boat tour Also did the glass bottom boat tour via Terry / Power 2 boat cost $110tt pp.   It seemed to me that our boat we were on was not as nice as some of the others around (Cool Runnings) but really I think any boat you go on would‚Äôve fine. They all do the same thing. There are a few bars / restaurant take out options on the beach.   We mostly got drinks and ice cream. The ice cream shop there has the best homemade coconut ice cream!! Get some. Ask Terry to bring you to the roti place (Trinbago Curry House) down the road ($100tt for a massive roti!) or to bring you local food.  So yummy and cheap. He will bring it to you right on the beach. If you need or want a driver or a hook up with anything while in this area, call or msg Terry.  He works the pier area and is amazing to deal with.   Tell him Connie from Canada sent you.  He has connections for anything you need and can bring you any place you like. Great trustworthy driver. Tel/ whatsapp (868) 302 6964 or Terry Tours & Rental

This is the better beach at the southern end of Tobago.  We went when there were no cruise ships in so please bear this in mind as I suspect it would be a magnet for people off loading for the day. Entrance price is for all day, however we only had 30 mins due to us having to catch a flight.  if you only want to pop in and look you can pay the price and then get it refunded on the way out so long as you stay no longer than 30 mins.  Enough time for a walk around, photoshoot and a paddle.... saying that we wish we had longer.  There were good amenities (toilets/ showers) cafes in keeping with the location, a pier and what looked like trips out to Nylon Pool.  If we return to Tobago we will book all day here to chill out.

This beach is so breathtaking...water is calm and lovely. Such a relaxing beach, a must visit when in Tobago. You have to pay a fee to enter the beach, elders with an ID on them are free. There is also restaurants, bars and ice cream stalls on the beach...everything at your fingertips.

This just has to be among the most beautiful beaches in the world. It costs about ¬£2.60 sterling to go into the park and is worth every penny. There are a few souvenir shops and a couple of bars...but the views are what this place is about. Make sure you take your camera. Oh, and it has really good free wifi access!
Just spent second trip to pigeon point , it's a beautiful beach with all the facility's you could want , would highly recommend a visit

I went by myself, so I was especially concerned about safety, however it seems to be a secure area.  You have to pass a gatehouse to get in, and pay $20 for use of the facilities.  There are washrooms, showers, covered shelters, picnic tables included in the admission price, and concession stands and bars, and chaise lounge rentals are extra.  There are also some souvenir shops.  There are jet-ski rentals at the far end of the beach, and you can take a glass-bottom boat tour from the jetty.  Beautiful sandy beach and warm water.  There are "no soliciting" signs up everywhere, but I did get approached by a man trying to sell me a tour.  When I declined, he had a nasty retort for me but he left quickly, since he was not supposed to be doing that.  Relatively speaking, Pigeon Point is better than other areas in terms of not being harassed.

Spend the TT and have a great day.... superb beaches and the little bars and shops are great. You can walk across white sand and palm tree covered beaches,check out the Turtle hatching beaches, swim in lovely clear water have drinks food , water sports and even boat trips.... it‚Äôs endless. Great place to visit

Visited pigeon point beach a couple days ago. The beach is clean and well Maintained. It only cost $20.00 tt to enter the facility.  There a numerous cabanas for shading and one can also rent beach chairs at a minimal cost. There are boutiques and restaurants at the facility as well as water sports. I defenitely recommend this beach while visiting
Visited the beach, it is the best, the atmosphere is great, staff are very helpful, just love Pigeon Point beach.

Great area and atmosphere to spend a waterfront day.  There is a 20TT$ (about $3 US) cover charge to enter the park....but it is worth it and kept wonderful. Shops, eateries and lots of sun to catch up with.

Its a very very friendly place the bar has lovely cocktails the food in the same bar is a buffet its amazing the twins are helpful though not smiley sometimes but its a beautiful beach and a must visit
Beach was beautiful and water was calm.  There was a life guard on duty.   We ate at one of the cabanas and the food was plentiful and very tasty.   Nice music for entertainment.

Pigeon Point must be on every postcard, yes you have to pay to enter and park, but it is worth every cent The beach is stunning, there are good facilities, shower rooms as well as loos, plenty of bars, food etc Hummingbirds keep you company whilst you are enjoying some food and of course a rum punch, or two what more can I say, enjoy and in the cold dark winter in Englandget out the photos.....

This is what you expect a Caribbean beach to look like! 20TT entry per person but it's well worth it - much quieter than Store Bay, and with much better facilities too. There are two cafe/bars on the beach - one by the entrance, the other at the far end by the water sports area: both do food but we far preferred the bar by the water sports area which is quieter with (we thought) better food, at a similar price. You get the occasional seller promoting a tour or boat trip but they're very polite and not pushy. Police patrol the beach too and they are very friendly. If you are staying at the Magdalena Grande there's a free shuttle twice a day so you save 100TT each way taxi fare over going to Store Bay (where the shuttle doesn't stop). If you're waiting by the shops for the return shuttle, keep an eye open for the birds in the rockery plants opposite - including hummingbirds! This is a lovely lovely place and by far our favourite beach in Tobago.

Visited here a couple of times... 20tt to enter into the heritage park, just a short walk upto a very stunning beach, showers for men and women along with bars, food etc...the odd person will come upto you now and again for glass boat or jet skis...no idea of prices...overall a very stunning beach, very serene and quiet...lovely bit of paradise....

This beach is one of the best on the Island. It has 2 restaurant that serves liquor (Parents...lol) and water sports for the kids. The beach chair rental are $5 USD. The vendors are on the outside of the Beach selling cute floaties for the kids to have and nice souvenirs. You can totally relax here. Best time to go is around 11-4pm. The beach closes at 5:30; however, they start collecting beach chairs at 5pm. The also have a little shack that sells sodas, chips, ice cream and little candies.
Great beach to visit.  Clear white sands and calm blue waters.  Clean surroundings that is very well kept. Highly recommend to visitors.  You will not regret.
The Beach offers good washrooms, snackbars, boattrips, sunbeds rental and has White sand, natural shade and the atmospheres are really relaxing üòé
A place to go for a swim in the sea and relax on the beach whilst soaking up the Caribbean sun rays.
Awesomeness. Great all round experience.  Jet skis. Banana boats, nylon pool ride the food was soooo amazing. Just do it.

This is a lovely beach that is well-kept with lots of staff around.  You have to pay 20T&T dollars entry and another 30T&T for a lounger (so about ¬£6 UK?) but it is worth it.  Good toilets, beach buffet food and an ice-cream place, plus a couple of shops - but the main thing is soft white sand, gorgeous sunshine and crystal clear water to swim in.  My 14 year old son and I spent a few hours here on our last day before heading to the airport and it was perfect for that.  Glass bottom boat tours go out to Buccoo Reef and Nylon Pool from here as well, if you have time for those - sadly we didn't.  People are friendly and will come and talk to you, particularly to see if you want a tour, but there are no hawkers so the whole place just felt well-run and easygoing.
Pretty setting more touristy than many beaches in Tobago but a great place to spend a day. Very friendly people. Places to eat and bars. Perfect for families with young children.

My family and I spend the afternoon here after our trip to Store Bay and the Nylon pool. There is a nominal entrance fee per person. It felt private and we enjoy the beach, the bar (the food was outstanding-delicious red snapper!), and the jet skiing. Beware of the jet skiing "sales" guys, I had two different guys approach me, not realizing they weren't working together. Go with Andy, he's official.
I attended a wedding at the heritage park and also visit the beach another day. Some of the best views and the water is beautiful . Definitely a must see !
The most beautiful beaches I have ever seen. Magnificent sunset n sunrise. Variety of restaurants and pubs in the area.

We attended most days of our holiday as it has easy access for grandmother of 89 but on Tuesday 18th July our visit was completely ruined by a staff member who had a go first at a ten year old with autism for washing her feet with shoes on and wasting water, then at myself for using water - then the rest of our family and the next people who washed their feet ( now bare in mind there is a notice saying wash your feet before using the toilets and even more interestingly it rained the whole day all 14 of us were there! Quite a few tourists and families from Trinidad had still visited the beach even though it was raining and spent the whole day there in the rain - yet she decided to have a go at the people who braved the rain!) The next day Grandmother and the young children did not want to return to this beach as they did not like her shouting at them.

A really lovely beach and recently has been cleaned up very well. You have to pay to get on it now but it has made it a lot safer and the amenities are so much better. The beautiful white sand and clear blue waters make it very safe for children. There are lots of water sports you can do at a cost and you can get some nice food also. A place you must really visit when you go to Tobago

I get that some people are unhappy about paying a tiny amount to get into this facility, but, they use that money to manage the beach and parking to an excellent standard.
