There was no littler, parking was managed and there are excellent changing facilities and shops. The beach and the water is clean and just beautiful. I went on a Sunday so there were plenty of families enjoying their day and it was great to see. I had lunch at Renmars (a separate review) and the only criticism there was that there was no air con. First world problem! The food was great. Plenty to do - lounge on the beach, jets, swim, stand up paddle boarding, kayaking, (from the sports shop) and there are some little shops. Looking out to the Nylon Pool the vista is stunning and all that you could ask for in a Caribbean view!

There is a small entrance fee to me which it is totally worth it. Bathrooms are clean, cabanas available, You can purchase food ,homemade ice cream, there is also full bars. Boats to Nylon pool and jet skis to rent.. It was totally fun
Between lounging on the shore, sipping on drinks, liming on the jetty or taking a glass bottom boat tour, i''m not sure which is the reason i love pigeon point the most.

The beach itself is beautiful You have to pay a small fee to get in the park but it is so worth it! The water is your picture perfect caribbean color. One thing I didnt like is the guys runing around trying to get you to go on their boat trip or their Jet Skis... I know it is their job but it can get annoying after the 10th time in one day. The food is ok there.

We visited Pigeon point last month. The beach itself is very nice but we didn't like the whole touristy thing going on. People trying to get you to go on boat trips. One after the other. Very noisy as well after some of the beautiful and quiet beaches we visited. Also beware of parking under the trees. I had a huge branch fall on the roof of my hire car causing quite a bit of damage. Luckily I paid CDR on my insurance so it didn't cost me anything. The management quite frankly didn't give a stuff. Overall I would not visit again

Awesome beach to hang out at for a day. Water is really clear, beach is clean, bathroom facilities aren't the best but OK. Only downside was the food available. Maybe pack your own lunch if you want something fresh and not fried.

Such a beautiful beach! A nominal fee to enter (20TTD - about ¬£2) but there are great facilities - clean toilets, showers, restaurants and bars. The beach is gorgeous with crystal clear turquoise sea! It wasn't too busy or crowded. From here you can get on a glass bottomed boat to the reef and nylon pool or arrange a snorkelling trip. Take towels. You can hire a sun lounger for about 30TTD. Some people took their own picnic but there are places to buy food too. The view is unbelievable. It feels so peaceful and tranquil. It is also the image of Tobago so a must see!

Beautiful, tranquil beach. Nominal fee to enter (supports upkeep of facilities) Last Sunday of every month it's free. Make sure to try the local ice creams(nutmeg and barbadine are just two) Rum punch is a must from Renmar's (they're the bar furthest from the entrance, not the first bar you meet) and follow it up with a Carib and a Stag, the local beers, to have your say in an ages long debate among the locals as to which one is best. A walk along the jetty is also a first-timers tradition.

If you want to do jet skis, a small boat tour, and snorkeling, and bathe in the Nylon pool enjoy! Pigeon point is enjoyable. I loved Nylon pool and No Man's land, but when I get back to the main area, I hate all of the beach staff being aggressive and asking if I want to do activities for them. It's a hustle for them and they compete with each other and it can spoil the moment at the beach. You have to pay to enter. It's fun and youthful but not for a quality day with family. The food is good there though.

Pigeon Point Beach is the place to be if ever you are visiting the island of Tobago. It is a natural beauty and you can participate in a number of water sports or take a short visit to the Buccoo reef or Nylon Pool.

Best beach in Tobago as far as I'm concerned! Crystal clear blue water, fine white sand, overhanging palm trees, and a great view. In early June, there were only a couple dozen people there. Very close to hotels, walkable to downtown, and good food and facilities.

20 min walk from Coco Reef Hotel at the entrance you pay TT20 each to help with the upkeep of the grounds.  As you walk through there is a jetty right in front and as we walked to the end the sea was an incredible turquoise blue stunning!!! The beach was clean with all facilities catered for there were huts too where you could eat your picnic or shelter from the rain.  We had lunch at Renmars they made up boxes of delicious food where we ate outside with chilled beers lovely!!!! The sea was lovely to swim in and safe for children we did take our snorkelling gear but did not use it as nothing to look at. Had a lovely chilled out day a worthy visit!

We walked to this beach as we were staying at nearby coco reef resort. Small entrance fee but well worth it. Part of a protected heritage park and turtle nesting site, very clean, plenty of facilities and small bars and shops. Soft sand, great views and safe swimming.
Just gorgeous. Not too crowded, no trash on the beach, water is calm and warm. Paradise. I will come back!

Such a gorgeous beach BUT it rained every time we visited as suspect it does this often.  We were there in March and everyone said this was unusual.  I'm not so sure as when we drove back to Grafton Beach it was generally dunn and we could see the clouds hanging over Pigeon Point.  If you visit there's a great restaurant on the beach often serving goat curry and very reasonably priced.

You have to pay a small charge to visit pigeon point but it is definitely worth it. The beach is clean and there's toilets on site. You can do water sports or go on a glass bottom boat to view the coral.
A trip over the reef with snorkel stop and on to the nylon pool brilliant day well worth it ! Even though the shuttle bus from store bay to Bon accord was very dodgy!!

Great flat water windsurfing spot. Turtles pop up, lovely beach, nice easygoing restaurants and bars. Around the corner you do not feel the wind at all, its just quiet beach life under the palm trees. note: you need an access pass to be able to get to Crown Point. few dollars per day.

I have been to the beautiful island of Tobago but this was my first visit to Pigeon Point Beach. I never knew what I was missing until I visited this place. I vow to visit this beach every time I visit Tobago in the future. There are eat and drinks as well as ice-cream on sale. There are tour guides to Nylon Pool and Buccoo Reef in abundance.

Probably the most popular beach on the island.  Lots of space, almost like a state park.  Facilities including bars and restaurants.  One side is windy (kite surfing etc) and the other side is calmer.   There is a small entrance fee to the park.

Since we were staying on the Atlantic side of the island with its darker waters, my husband was lamenting the lack of his Caribbean beach experience. But when we got into this beach, he said: This is it, I got my experience. Emerald waters, white sand, clean beach, palm trees and other lovely mature, bathrooms, showers, free beach lounger chairs, huts and roofed areas, a restaurant, close parking, and life guards. Access to boats to the Nylon Pool if you want them. Lovely. Definitely worth a visit.

Took at 12-20 min Caribbean Airlines flight from Trinidad to Tobago. There is a fee to enter Pigeon Point as this is one of the better beaches, not many locals more touristy ...I must say WELL WORTH it... the beach has breath taking views and the water was so warm. I recommend taking one of the boats out to the Nylon Pool... one of the best excursions, I have been on in any island. The water is warm with sand that is suppose to leave your skin looking ten years younger. The water is very shallow so you can stand up.. its amazing. I recommend bringing a water proof camera as the views are breathtaking. The boat ride was only $100 TT ($15 USD).. A must visit while in Tobago ...

Pigeon Point definitely has its advantages. Clean washrooms, friendly people (Anthony the Lifeguard aka Michael Clark Duncan) and lovely almost trees for lounging under. Having access to good food and drinks is also great. That being said, we still prefer the beaches elsewhere. It didn't quite live up to the hype.
Pigeon Point is the heart of Tobago! It is BEAUTIFUL. You cannot go to TObago and not been to Pigeon point. The flowers, the view, the activities, the beach. A MUST!
Do not leave Tobago without a day at Pigeon Point. You have to pay a small enter fee but well worth it.

I went to Pigeon Point expecting to be amazed following other reviews but was under-the-counter with the whole place. I was expecting the TT20 per person admission and TT30 per person chair-bed and didn't bother with paying for umbrellas but I didn't realise that with a captive market food and drink prices would be above-said (Carib Tt15, Single Scoop Ice-cream TT18). Despite the enclosed aspect it did not keep out the touts trying to sell you tours also at above average prices. We had travelled on the same Glass-Bottomed Boat from Store Bay the previous day (no charge for entering the area). But what an area I hear you saying. It is true that the area is very pretty, but when entering the sea, the sea-floor in the lifeguard area was covered in seaweed. Tobago has many other beaches without these problems, I will be going elsewhere and I suggest that you do also.

I had such an amazing time at pigeon point beach. I took a ride out on "juicy lips" the glass bottom boat which stopped at 3 locations and allowed us to see the coral reefs and fish. The first stop allowed people to go snorkeling, the next stop was a party in the ocean where a bunch of boats stopped while playing music in the middle of the Caribbean sea. The water was shallow and okay for kids.The final stop was a small part of the island where people can enjoy some more fun in the sun. The beach was well kept and gorgeous.
No complaints - wide variety of local foods - crab and dumplings is pretty much what you would want to eat here....

I enjoyed my two days liming at this jaw dropping beach. I could've stayed for weeks. I visited during Spring Break & on a weekend and it wasn't crowded. Arrived at the beach around noon & got chairs & umbrellas to rent. There is an entry fee to the park but is minimal maybe $20TT for the beauty of the place. I arranged a glass bottom boat tour the first day around the area of Nylon Pool and did some snorkeling as well. There is a beach bar & several places to buy food, drinks, ice cream, cold beer, souvenirs, swimwear, beach towels, water shoes etc. The bathrooms were clean for changing as well as some showers to rinse off sand. Lifeguards are on duty & I heard whistles a few times to keep swimmers safe.  Plenty of palms for shade & places for direct sun as well. This is the place where tropical calendars are made so walk around & get some amazing views of this stunning place.

We visited Pigeon point on 3 occasions whilst in Tobago üáπüáπ there is an iconic jetty with a thatch cover at the end which makes for Done awesome photos. There are a few shops there to purchase some gifts to come home with. You can get a jet ski out or book trips with the various tour guides but if you don't want to say no thanks have a laugh with them and they move onto the next tourist without any pressure. There is a small charge to get in but it's worth paying you even get free wifi!!
The most popular beach in Tobago it offers everything you need for a day on the beach, restaurants, bars, water sports and beach beds.

Perfect location with a white sandy beach. Nice eating places and airport close by. Nice walk along the beach. Can busy on weekends when locals and tourists visit the island for the weekend. Worth visiting
Visited a dear friend in Tobago. Natural island beauty with no tourist traps. Complete relaxation...
truly amazing beach..beautiful soft sand and clear waters also alot of helpful staff around where you can rent chairs and buy food/drinks

Perhaps the best beach in Tobago, it's well kept, very clean and quite safe. You can't get bored with all the water sports available, although you can choose just to lay back and relax. We were lucky enough to get a beach hut (go early to get one) so we setup our cooler with drinks and our basket with food and snacks and had a picnic on the beach, however there are a few restaurants and a fully stocked bar on the beach. Swimming is great, the water is very calm and clear, and there are areas for snorkeling. If you so choose, tours are available to Nylon Pool, Buccoo Reef and No Mans Land. Definitely a must see for all visiting Tobago, very picturesque.

We enjoyed an afternoon at this beach! There was plenty of activities to choose from. We needed up renting a "jet ski" for an hour. The machines were in good conditions - sea had some chop which made for extra fun. Big playground. The beach was good for swimming. Food was available as were drinks. We were mixing our own drinks and no one bothered us. Showers were available for free. No on bothered us to buy anything!

My love and I took in the sunset on this beach yesterday. There weren't many people there at the time which made it very enjoyable. The waves were nice and the atmosphere was cool. The bars had begun playing some 90's rock, which I enjoyed so we had an excellent time.

Excellent beach with good facilities around. Small entrance fee, and small charge if you want to rent a sunlounger. The beach is beautiful, clean and well maintained. The current is quite strong but has life guards watching over you. Plenty of changing facilities, shower and toilets all along the Point. A reasonably good selection of food available too at ok prices. Bit off the beaten track but is within walking distance of Crown Point, or a short hop by taxi. This is a place you can spend the entire day at.

Great beach with bar and quick food. Also offering tour on a glass bottom boat in the sea. Entrance to the beach costs 20tt and at the beach you can also rent a chair for 30tt and an umbrella 30tt. Beach also provide free wifi.

For a minimal fee, you have access to a well maintained secured property.  Beautiful grounds, clean beach, a variety of vendors, and of course the Jetty if you wish to do the Reef and Nylon Pool.  A definite must do.

Unfortunately you do have to pay to enter but it is only TTD20. This helps to maintain the beautiful facilities. There are gorgeous 270 degree views from here. Also the most photographed jetty in the world is here.
My husband and I just relax and admired this beautiful surrounding - we ate, drank and I went into the waters. It was warm and calming. I just sat and let the water surround me

When you dream of a white sand Caribbean beach this is it! Totally safe and secure in a landscaped park lots of facilities for eating and drinking even when busy nothing can spoil the crystal clear warm waters behind a reef so entirely calm for hours of blissful swimming.

Our hotel supplied a bus for two return trips a day to Pigeon Point. The area is beautiful with a stunning sheltered beach. It would be rude not to accept. There are 'wet or dry' boat trips, trinket shops, cafes, bars and a choice of water sports to keep you busy. All good stuff for a very modest fee. What was more concerning was the considered need for a fairly large number of security staff. Furthermore, there are signs everywhere "don't do this." Don't do that." Totally unnecessary.

We come every year to a family house and would never dream of not coming to this beach. You pay $15 tt to get in, this pays for the grounds to be kept well, toilet blocks etc. We have been coming for years and it's good to see the facilities getting better.

Really beautiful romantic long beach with a nice Jetty ... it's just a perfect and amazing. You need to pay an entrance fee for this beach and a taxi to get there from Tobago Airport, would be a good idea to have a pick up arranged on return. Should not be missed
Very nice beach. U pay entry, about 20TTD but u'll get a nice, clean beach with nice people. A lot of activities

If you‚Äôre not renting a car, then prepare to spend a lot to get to Pigeon Point and to enjoy the day. If you‚Äôre staying in the Crown Point/Store Bay area, then easiest and probably most cost-effective way to get here is to stand on Milford road and flag down a local taxi who will charge you about TT$20 for a short-drop. A proper taxi will be about $50 one-way. Entry is $20 each and $30 each to rent a lounger (!). So cost to get to and from Pigeon Point and to just sit on the beach is about TT$140 to TT$200 (US$30) for a couple. There are a few wooden benches but these fill up fast so you have no chance to secure any spot to sit if you go after 11am. When we visited it was so crowded! Most people couldn‚Äôt even find a patch of sand to spread a towel! They say that the huts are available but the majority were cordoned off with caution tape. There were people like ants! Piece of advice: If you‚Äôre looking for a peaceful day at Pigeon point then don‚Äôt go on Friday, Saturday or Sunday! Best if you could arrange your return transport when you get dropped off as it‚Äôs pot luck really if there happens to be a taxi waiting and available to take you back to your hotel. Decent food options like Traditions Restaurant which serves Shell-less curried crab & dumplings! Yum! There‚Äôs local food being served as well as a fast food place and several bars, and even an ice cream place. The water was freezing cold when we visited. The water was murky ‚Äì it‚Äôs not as clear as it used to be. Also, there were lots of bits of coral and seaweed underfoot which made bathing somewhat unpleasant. But Pigeon Point is a cool place for liming and people-watching even if you‚Äôre not swimming. I‚Äôd say if you‚Äôre taxiing there and back, bring about TT$500 cash to cover your transport, lounging and food needs, more if you‚Äôre planning to patronise the souvenir shops.

This beach is absolutely worth visiting! The entrance itself is inviting with tall swaying palms. There's a small fee to enter, which was worth it because the beach was clean and so were its washroom facilities.  You can rent chairs on the beach for about $5/day pp.  The beach had and area which was calm for swimming. If you continue and walk around the bend, the water gets a bit more rough. There were all kinds of people wind-surfing on the rougher/windy side. If snorkelling or visiting the Nylon Pool is on your list of activities to do, you will find many people hustling about, to take you for about $20US.  The glass bottom boats will pick you up at the pier directly on this beach.
Visited most of the local beaches while staying in Buccoo Tobago. Beautiful crystal clear turquoise blue water with lots of different tropical fish close by for some snorkelling views. Loved it!

When I asked a Tobagonian what the best beach was in Tobago she said Pigeon Point without hesitating and now I know why. It has a bit of everything parts of the beach are reserved for bathers of course, water sport enthusiasts, party people, families and for those like me who just wanted to take a leisurely walk. Pigeon Point is not at all far from Milford Road the main road where everything is in Crown Point so please DO NOT get conned into hiring a cab to take you there as you can easily walk it in about 15 minutes. I spent a good while strolling along taking photographs and drinking in the magnificent scenery with my eyes. Some cliches are good, in this case it was exactly like a postcard with palm trees, white sand and a cool breeze caressing your skin. If you are driving into Crown Point there is a 20 TTD admission fee to use the facilities. I was walking along the beach there was no charge for me naturally. To be honest I thought the charge to be rather cheeky as there was nowhere for me to place my things safely in order to take a dip in the incredibly inviting water. If you're in a group fine, as you can leave belongings with your people. If you are alone however then you are left with no choice but to forego a swim, a shame really. There are places to eat and drink which were constantly busy when I was there and a really good atmosphere as people ate, drank and listened to music. When you keep on walking you'll pass all the folks windsurfing, jet skiing and the like then further on from there the beach gets progressively quieter and quieter until you find yourself completely alone which I loved. I walked about as far as I possibly could; took some photos then turned back walking the entire length of the beach once again grabbing a few cold drinks on the way to the thick of things in town. I had a great tranquil, meditative time there though disappointed I could not enjoy the water as one can in Store Bay a beach that I prefer a little better than this one. Don't get me wrong Pigeon Point is stunning just a little impractical for lone strollers like me.

On Carnival Tuesday morning, unlike many other Trinbagonians, I went to Pigeon Point beach to see the sunrise. It was the most amazing and beautiful sight. I practically had the whole beach to myself and it so peaceful. Later in the evening, I went back and enjoyed the cool blue waters.
Beach area beautiful sunset food and drinks on sale calm sea most times good swimming kite surfing and jet skies for rent

Got in late, did a stroll, stunning setting, took a few pics of the dock and hut over the water, the signs light up nicely with a flash creating a unique look. Suggest trying pics with the flash on in the day to set off the signs, try and see.

Great beach! Very clean and plenty of bars/restaurants to hang out at. I costs 20TT to get in and there is plenty to do here. Kite surfing, jet skis, and other water sports. There's also a glass bottom boat that several of my friends went on and had a blast. I had a great time watching the people doing tricks in the water. I walked up and down the beach had a few drinks at the bars, Played pool, got some decent food at Renmars. Highly recommend this beach for younger crowd looking to relax and have fun!

If you're looking to lime on a beautiful beach then pigeon point is the best place to go. Lots of amenities and activities. It costs 20tt dollars per person but it's worth the entrance fee. And of course a visit to the coral reef and the nylon pool is a must expect to pay 120tt dollars per person.

Yes I finally made it to Tobago and Pigeon Point Beach. First off, it does cost 20TT per person to enter and 30TT if you want a lounge chair. However, I felt the price was worth it given that this beach has places to eat, drink, and provides washrooms with showers for the entry fee. For those not wanting a lounge chair, if you get here early enough you will be able to use picnic tables for free and the sand is soft enough to lie on. The water is clam, and clear blue which allows you to snorkel but much like the other beach areas you don't have much to see. There are shade trees on the beach so you can even get away without renting an umbrella. I enjoyed my day here as it was relaxing with minimal hawkers and a good mix of people. I highly recommend spending a day here if you want to chill.
Crystalline blue water, jet skis, glass bottom boats, a trip to the Nylon Pool 1/2 mile away... Pigeon Point is simply breath taking. You must go. You must enjoy.
Pigeon point, is the ideal beach if you don't want to fight the underwater currents and you just want to swim like if you were in a pool! Love it!

Surprised that there was an entrance fee to the beach. The water was really rough that day and it made it difficult for us to go in especially since we wanted to go snorkeling. We did meet someone who had a boat who took us out to a rehab so that we could go snorkeling with another couple. He was terrific and I'm sorry I don't remember his name or the name of the boat. We had lunch there which was OK.  However, when we walked on the beach and wanted to sit on some chairs there, someone came up and said it cost more money to sit on a chair! It was mediocre to say best about it

There's an entrance fee, but at the end of day you feel like the cost should have been double. Just find your spot under a shady tree and enjoy the waves break out at the reefs. Stroll the beach and lend your lens to the water activities, such a jet skiing, canoeing, kite surfing, or lend your ears to the island vibes from a passing tour boat like Easy Running's. The water is so clear that you'll say to yourself this must be paradise. Don't forget your camera because the sunset you'll need to capture until your next visit.

As in the safest and the cleanest. The entrance fee (20 TT) makes a big difference, helps keeping the beach and grounds clean. A chair will cost you 30TT. you get 2 tags on your hand, one for chair one for the access to the beach. It is packed during weekends though. You have to go early to get a good spot. I went there twice, one day to check it around and another day when I supposed to go diving and the boat broke down so I had to spend the day on the beach. It has a few shops and restaurants, ice cream kiosk too. Clean washrooms too. Large water sports base. It has everything you need not to go anywhere else from the beach. ZIt is a long beach. you can walk alot and sun bath in a less used area, but away form the shops and restaurants. see my pictures, It is the safest beach in Tabago. many tourits pick Pigeon point for that. Also being close to Crown Point which is the safest town in Tobago makes the beach crowded at times.
Fantastic location for the family to kick back and relax in beautiful Tobago. Would definitely return. :)

Beautiful beach, white sand, clear water, and very clean.  The toilet facilities are good.  Nice bar with good food.  A few shops selling everything you need.  Sometimes get crowded when the cruise ships are in port.  You can get lots of trips from here.  The locals are chatty and friendly no need to be rude to them they are just trying to make a living, if you talk to them but say no to the trip they will leave you alone.  We arrange a boat trip with Frankie tours, brilliant day.  Got collected from the hotel about 9.30 on the boat along the coast stopping off to swim or snorkel, seeing stunning beaches and scenery.  Saw a pod of dolphins which made our day, caught a fish for lunch.  Stopped off at No Mans Beach for a BBQ of chicken, fish, green banana salad, rice and a few other local dishes - delicious. Went to Nylon Pool.  Highly recommend this trip.  Got back to the hotel about 5.30.  Well worth a visit to Pigeon Point and worth the TT$20
Love this beach, sea is calm one side and quite the opposite on the other,  very picturesque with many places to eat and drink.  Does get busy at times but definitely worth a day.

We went there on a Sunday morning. In order to rent a chair, you have to buy a ticket from a booth then go to the chair guy. We arrived at about 9:20 and the ticket lady didn‚Äôt come until about 10:00. The sand on the beach is very fine and soft, so doesn‚Äôt stick to your feet like other beaches. In the water, however, I suggest water shoes. There are stones and shells in the water that will annoy your feet if they are sensitive. The hawkers for boat rides are annoying but usually take ‚Äòno‚Äô for an answer. If you are looking for a snorkel, jet ski, glass-bottom boat, or any other water activity, there are plenty of vendors to pick from. There are two places to eat. There is a snack shack for hot dogs, chicken, fish, fries. And a restaurant for higher level meals like BBQ sandwiches. There are about five gift shops. There are a dozen huts that aren‚Äôt occupied. Most shops have anything you could want for souvenirs. We do try to get to Pigeon Point at least once when we visit Tobago.
Very nice beach with all the services, there's an entry fee but it's not bad. When in Tobago you need to go there at least once.

This is my favourite spot to spend a day at the beach. $3 admission , $5 for a beach chair, beers, food (the local ice cream my fav). Swimmimg, snorkeling or watching the para-sailing at the end of the beach while enjoying the calypso music under clear blue skies in the shade of a coconut tree is my idea of relaxation. This is my Must to Go place whenever I visit Tobago!

This is without a doubt the clearest water in all shades of blue.. and great sand just as you would see in a Caribbean beach brochure. You have to pay TT$ 20 per person per day for entry.. and they give you an armband. There's plenty parking if you bring a car. The boardwalk with a thatchroof hut is apparently one of the most photographed areas in Tobago. The area you can swim in is roped and manned by lifeguards. Though the most touristy beach on the island, it didn't feel overcrowded. Stalls sell stuff including beach needs.

Spent a day at the this beautiful spot on several occasions. Very scenic and pretty. Beach was spectacular with easy entry to the water. Lots of options available in the way of sports,food and fun. Costs for entry was 20TT(3 US).

Chose a tour that went to this beach all be it for a short time. Went as in England somebody who has lived on Tobago for three years said it was a must. However whilst it is beutifull so are many beaches in Tobago a bit overrated .

So we did have to pay $3USD to get into the park, but once we were in, it was very nice. The bar was very crowded and full of tourists. The drinks were very expensive, and all food is served in styrofoam containers, which isn't very environmentally friendly. But the swimming was fun.

you have to pay but all this does is put Americans/Canadians together & who needs that. Picture postcard ? lots of beaches in Tobago are. Best approached from the sea Toilets are worse than elsewhere and round the corner to the windy side there's lots of litter so what exactly are you paying for ? drinks are more expensive than anywhere else its much better & quieter if you stop off before the entrance to the point

Pigeon Point is also known as Pigeon Point Heritage Park  and is often thought of as Tobago‚Äôs most beautiful beach. It is located on Tobago's south-western coast.  It is about 2 km walk from the Tropikist hotel where we were staying. Just walk along the main road past Milford Fort past Crown Point Hotel and Store Bay beach, past the Coco Reef Hotel and look for the signs ( Pigeon Point road branches off from Milford Road) or ask someone the way as everyone knows Pigeon Point. The white sandy beach is beautiful and there  are excellent beach facilities such as bathrooms, showers and beach-chair rentals as well as bars and a restaurant. Boat trips can be booked from here as well. It is open from 9am to 5pm and costs 20 TT for adults (about ¬£2.25) and 10 for children to get in. You can apparently buy a weekly ticket if you want to go every day. There  are souvenir and water-sports shops and lifeguards are on duty. On the way to Pigeon Point you can stop at other smaller beaches that you do not need to pay for, however at least one visit is worth it just to see what it has to offer.

One of the most picturesque and unblemished beaches visited. The surroundings are resplendent and clean and tidy. Plenty of sunbeds to rent and places serving food and drink. It is definitely an unmissable experience.

We visited Pigeon Point on at least six occasions during our stay in Tobago without doubt their Jewel in the crown, it is beautiful, clean,lots to do friendly people good food, snorkelling Glass Bottom boat tour, surfing, jet skis and much more. The day seems to fly by there is so much to do, like most of these attractions can be costly with entrance fee, sunbed hire overpriced snacks ice creams etc, however do not let this put you off Paradise

Nice beach, nice sand and beautiful surrounding. The problem is that its far too crowded and when every other beach in Tobago is a postcard beach with a lot less people and sometimes even empty, this was not our first choice coming here.

We were in Tobago for just one day on our two week cruise and we chose this beach to visit in the afternoon as a rest from our hike up to Fort St, George in the morning.  We shared a taxi from the port with another couple and agreed a three hour stay with the driver.  In fact I think he parked up and had a wee siesta! There is a $3 US per person fee to get in as it is a park and thus greater security and cleaner although it wasn't spotless.  The toilets, changing rooms and external showers were free and clean and very welcome to rinse off the salt.  There are a few kiosks and bars but with the GBP exchange rate being very poor, on account of the Brexit vote (not me!) we found the prices for food and drink very high and the hire of the beach beds and umbrellas equally so.  You can of course just put your mat or towel on the sand as many did. The day was very windy but the beach closest to the entrance was sheltered although the sea too stirred up for snorkelling.  Around the corner at the northern beach it was very rough and being enjoyed by lots of wind and kite surfers.  A lovely place and I also found my 1000th geocache just outside the entrance gate which was fun.

Before we came to Tobago (my first visit to the Caribbean and to celebrate my 70th birthday) I asked my husband for a white sandy beach, aquamarine gentle sea, palm trees, blue sky, warm temperature  (30¬∞nice)bit of breeze, beachbar/restaurants and peace. Not a lot to ask but this area has it all and I LOVED IT!! Thank you darling.

We love Pigeon Point Beach.  Despite being built up over the years, it maintains its charm with the beautiful, crystal clear waters and the amazing trangquility that can be found especially during the week and non-peak hours.  Go early to secure a good spot at one of the little cabanas on the beach.  You can take a lesisure stroll, rent snorkel equipment or take on a jet ski adventure or parasailing; or like we did, just laze on the beach all day.   Great family or couples fun!!

This place is a must see if you go to Tobago.  So, so beautiful with white sands, turquoise sea and the typical leaning palm trees over the water. The food outlets are terrible and I would advise you either to take your own food or give the cafes/restaurants a miss.  They are truly terrible.  Such a shame in a country that has such great food!!! You have to pay TT$20 to get in but it is worth it even if you're only going to stay for an hour or two.

I just got back from a very interesting trip to Tobago. One of the highlights was this amazing beach resort area. Tobago itself doesn't appear to be very well-maintained, but the beach was pristine. I was only there for a couple hours, and I wish I could've stayed there all day! There is a 20 Trinadad dollar entry fee so be aware of that. Beautiful beach, warm water, lots to see and do here. It felt safe and it wasn't too crowded.

After visiting Maracas Bay in Trinidad I was pleasantly surprised by the much better amenities at this beach. It also is a great starting point to take a glass bottom boat tour to Nylon Pool or rent jet skis or kayaks. The beach itself is fairly clean and the water is beautiful. It's not the largest beach, but wasn't nearly as congested as I'm used to in Naples, FL in "season."  There were local food options and a nice bar available as well. I had a great time and recommend one of the glass bottom boat tours as well. Make sure you buy tickets on the beach though, because all the internet prices you find or about 3 times as expensive.

Can't argue that this is a lovely beach to spend the day at, with the option of taking own refreshments or buying from a choice of outlets. A box of chips and Carib were $15TT each, which we thought was reasonable for the location. There are a number of huts which are well maintained and provide good shelter, with plenty of tables and benches under trees as well. There were also a number of  life guards on patrol, and the water sports salesmen were friendly and not too pushy. The water was lovely and we had an amazing glass bottom boat trip snorkelling on the reef and swimming in the nylon pool with Rennie from Ringo Tours on his boat Three Tri & First Tri. Unfortunately, the owners seem to be relying on reputation and should make more of an effort as the #1 beach in Tobago. For example, the lovely golden sandy beach was not swept and was covered in leaves, seaweed and fag ends. The $18 chairs advertised on the website had clearly not been available for some time. One of the toilet blocks was out of use. Shops are understaffed with the ice cream seller closed for lunch. Overall, I would go back, but it's a shame that standards look like they are starting to slip.

Great idyllic beach, clear sand and spectacular blue water. Entrance fee is 20 TT dollars (1 us = 6.77 TTD). Swiming zone protected by bouys, there are lifeguards. A few restaurants and little bars (a beer is 15 ttd, beachchairs rental 5 us all day).
Beach was nice, but really nothing unusual. More touristy than not, but still not with much of interest.
